title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Remarks+on+becoming+Prime+Minister%3C%2Fi%3E+%28St+Francis%27s+prayer%29&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.margaretthatcher.org%2Fdocument%2F115355&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMargaret+Thatcher" class="Z3988"></span><sup id="cite_ref-Prayer_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Prayer-111">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup></td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p>Thatcher became prime minister on 4 May 1979. Arriving at <a href="/wiki/Downing_Street" title="Downing Street">Downing Street</a> she said, paraphrasing the <a href="/wiki/Prayer_of_Saint_Francis" title="Prayer of Saint Francis">Prayer of Saint Francis</a>:\n</p>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><div class="poem">\n<p>Where there is discord, may we bring harmony;<br />\nWhere there is error, may we bring truth;<br />\nWhere there is doubt, may we bring faith;<br />\nAnd where there is despair, may we bring hope.<sup id="cite_ref-Prayer_111-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Prayer-111">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n</div></blockquote>\n<p>In office throughout the 1980s, Thatcher was frequently described as the most powerful woman in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBern198743Ogden19909,_12_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBern198743Ogden19909,_12-112">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Domestic_affairs">Domestic affairs</span></h3>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Minorities">Minorities</span></h4>\n<p>Thatcher was Opposition leader and prime minister at a time of increased racial tension in Britain. On the <a href="/wiki/1977_United_Kingdom_local_elections" title="1977 United Kingdom local elections">local elections of 1977</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">The Economist</a></i> commented: "The Tory tide swamped the smaller parties\xe2\x80\x94specifically the <a href="/wiki/National_Front_(UK)" title="National Front (UK)">National Front &#91;NF&#93;</a>, which suffered a clear decline from last year."<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">&#91;111&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup> Her standing in the polls had risen by 11% after a 1978 interview for <i><a href="/wiki/World_in_Action" title="World in Action">World in Action</a></i> in which she said "the British character has done so much for democracy, for law and done so much throughout the world that if there is any fear that it might be swamped people are going to react and be rather hostile to those coming in", as well as "in many ways &#91;minorities&#93; add to the richness and variety of this country. The moment the minority threatens to become a big one, people get frightened".<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">&#91;114&#93;</a></sup> In the 1979 general election, the Conservatives had attracted votes from the NF, whose support almost collapsed.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReitan200326Ward2004128_119-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReitan200326Ward2004128-119">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup> In a July 1979 meeting with Foreign Secretary <a href="/wiki/Lord_Carrington" class="mw-redirect" title="Lord Carrington">Lord Carrington</a> and Home Secretary <a href="/wiki/William_Whitelaw" class="mw-redirect" title="William Whitelaw">William Whitelaw</a>, Thatcher objected to the number of Asian immigrants, in the context of limiting the total of <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_boat_people" title="Vietnamese boat people">Vietnamese boat people</a> allowed to settle in the UK to fewer than 10,000 over two years.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Queen">The Queen</span></h4>\n<p>As prime minister, Thatcher met weekly with <a href="/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Queen Elizabeth II">Queen Elizabeth&#160;II</a> to discuss government business, and their relationship came under close scrutiny.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReitan200328Seward2001154_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReitan200328Seward2001154-121">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup> <a href="#CITEREFCampbell2011a">Campbell (2011a</a>, p.&#160;464) states:\n</p>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>One question that continued to fascinate the public about the phenomenon of a woman Prime Minister was how she got on with the Queen. The answer is that their relations were punctiliously correct, but there was little love lost on either side. As two women of very similar age \xe2\x80\x93 Mrs Thatcher was six months older \xe2\x80\x93 occupying parallel positions at the top of the social pyramid, one the head of government, the other head of state, they were bound to be in some sense rivals. Mrs Thatcher\'s attitude to the Queen was ambivalent. On the one hand she had an almost mystical reverence for the institution of the monarchy [...] Yet at the same time she was trying to modernise the country and sweep away many of the values and practices which the monarchy perpetuated.</p></blockquote>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Michael_Shea_(diplomat)" title="Michael Shea (diplomat)">Michael Shea</a>, the Queen\'s press secretary, in 1986 leaked stories of a deep rift to <i>The Sunday Times</i>.  He said that she felt Thatcher\'s policies were "uncaring, confrontational and socially divisive".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPimlott1996460\xe2\x80\x93463,_484,_509\xe2\x80\x93514_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPimlott1996460\xe2\x80\x93463,_484,_509\xe2\x80\x93514-122">&#91;118&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher later wrote: "I always found the Queen\'s attitude towards the work of the Government absolutely correct [...] stories of clashes between \'two powerful women\' were just too good not to make up."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThatcher199318_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThatcher199318-123">&#91;119&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy_and_taxation">Economy and taxation</span></h4>\n<table class="mw-datatable floatright" style="margin:0 0 1.5em 1.5em;">\n<caption style="text-align:right;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r992953826"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Margaret_Thatcher/datatable" title="Template:Margaret Thatcher/datatable"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template_talk:Margaret_Thatcher/datatable&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template talk:Margaret Thatcher/datatable (page does not exist)"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Margaret_Thatcher/datatable&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div>\n</caption>\n<tbody><tr>\n<th colspan="2" height="40" style="font-size:85%; line-height:normal; text-align:center;">Economic growth and public spending<br /><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886047488">.mw-parser-output .nobold{font-weight:normal}</style><span class="nobold">% change in <a href="/wiki/Real_terms" class="mw-redirect" title="Real terms">real terms</a>: 1979/80 to 1989/90</span>\n</th></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:85%;">\n<th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal; text-align: left; width:15em;">Economic Growth (GDP)\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right; width:5em;"><span style="color:green;">+23.3</span>\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:85%;">\n<th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal; text-align: left;">Total government spending\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span style="color:green;">+12.9</span>\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:85%;">\n<th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal; text-align: left;"><span style="padding-left:1.0em;">&#160;</span>Law and Order\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span style="color:green;">+53.3</span>\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:85%;">\n<th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal; text-align: left;"><span style="padding-left:1.0em;">&#160;</span>Employment and Training\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span style="color:green;">+33.3</span>\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:85%;">\n<th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal; text-align: left;"><span style="padding-left:1.0em;">&#160;</span>NHS\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span style="color:green;">+31.8</span>\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:85%;">\n<th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal; text-align: left;"><span style="padding-left:1.0em;">&#160;</span>Social Security\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span style="color:green;">+31.8</span>\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:85%;">\n<th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal; text-align: left;"><span style="padding-left:1.0em;">&#160;</span>Education\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span style="color:green;">+13.7</span>\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:85%;">\n<th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal; text-align: left;"><span style="padding-left:1.0em;">&#160;</span>Defence\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span style="color:green;">+9.2</span>\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:85%;">\n<th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal; text-align: left;"><span style="padding-left:1.0em;">&#160;</span>Environment\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span style="color:green;">+7.9</span>\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:85%;">\n<th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal; text-align: left;"><span style="padding-left:1.0em;">&#160;</span>Transport\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span style="color: red;">&#8722;5.8</span>\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:85%;">\n<th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal; text-align: left;"><span style="padding-left:1.0em;">&#160;</span>Trade and Industry\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span style="color: red;">&#8722;38.2</span>\n</td></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:85%;">\n<th scope="row" style="font-weight: normal; text-align: left;"><span style="padding-left:1.0em;">&#160;</span>Housing\n</th>\n<td style="text-align: right;"><span style="color: red;">&#8722;67.0</span>\n</td></tr>\n</tbody><caption style="caption-side:bottom; font-size:90%; text-align:right;">Source: <a href="#CITEREFStewart2013">Stewart (2013</a>, "Appendix")\n</caption></table>\n<p>Thatcher\'s economic policy was influenced by <a href="/wiki/Monetarist" class="mw-redirect" title="Monetarist">monetarist</a> thinking and economists such as <a href="/wiki/Milton_Friedman" title="Milton Friedman">Milton Friedman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alan_Walters" title="Alan Walters">Alan Walters</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChilds2006185_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChilds2006185-124">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup> Together with her first <a href="/wiki/Chancellor_of_the_Exchequer" title="Chancellor of the Exchequer">chancellor</a>, <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_Howe" title="Geoffrey Howe">Geoffrey Howe</a>, she lowered direct taxes on income and increased indirect taxes.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReitan200330_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReitan200330-125">&#91;121&#93;</a></sup> She increased interest rates to slow the growth of the money supply and thereby lower inflation,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChilds2006185_124-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChilds2006185-124">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup> introduced cash limits on public spending, and reduced expenditure on social services such as education and housing.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReitan200330_125-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReitan200330-125">&#91;121&#93;</a></sup> Cuts to higher education led to Thatcher being the first Oxford-educated, post-war incumbent without an honorary doctorate from Oxford University, after a 738\xe2\x80\x93319 vote of the governing assembly and a student petition.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>\nSome Heathite Conservatives in the Cabinet, the so-called "<a href="/wiki/Wets_and_dries" title="Wets and dries">wets</a>", expressed doubt over Thatcher\'s policies.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">&#91;123&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/1981_England_riots" title="1981 England riots">1981 England riots</a> resulted in the British media discussing the need for a <a href="/wiki/Flip-flop_(politics)" title="Flip-flop (politics)">policy U-turn</a>. At the 1980 Conservative Party conference, Thatcher addressed the issue directly, with a speech written by the playwright <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Millar" title="Ronald Millar">Ronald Millar</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJones2007224_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJones2007224-128">&#91;124&#93;</a></sup> that notably included the following lines:<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942"/></p><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>To those waiting with bated breath for that favourite media catchphrase, the "U" turn, I have only one thing to say. "You turn if you want to. <a href="/wiki/The_lady%27s_not_for_turning" title="The lady&#39;s not for turning">The lady\'s not for turning</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup></p></blockquote>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/1981_United_Kingdom_budget" title="1981 United Kingdom budget">1981 budget</a></div>\n<p>Thatcher\'s job approval rating fell to 23% by December 1980, lower than recorded for any previous prime minister.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThornton200418_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThornton200418-130">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup> As the <a href="/wiki/Early_1980s_recession" title="Early 1980s recession">recession of the early 1980s</a> deepened, she increased taxes,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReitan200331_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReitan200331-131">&#91;127&#93;</a></sup> despite concerns expressed in a March 1981 statement signed by 364&#160;leading economists,<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">&#91;128&#93;</a></sup> which argued there was "no basis in economic theory [...] for the Government\'s belief that by deflating demand they will bring inflation permanently under control", adding that "present policies will deepen the depression, erode the industrial base of our economy and threaten its social and political stability".<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">&#91;129&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Margaret_Thatcher_visiting_Salford.jpg" class="image"><img alt="photograph" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Margaret_Thatcher_visiting_Salford.jpg/220px-Margaret_Thatcher_visiting_Salford.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="155" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Margaret_Thatcher_visiting_Salford.jpg/330px-Margaret_Thatcher_visiting_Salford.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Margaret_Thatcher_visiting_Salford.jpg/440px-Margaret_Thatcher_visiting_Salford.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2131" data-file-height="1502" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Margaret_Thatcher_visiting_Salford.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Thatcher during a visit to <a href="/wiki/Salford_University" class="mw-redirect" title="Salford University">Salford University</a> in 1982</div></div></div>\n<p>By 1982, the UK began to experience signs of economic recovery;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFloudJohnson2004392_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFloudJohnson2004392-134">&#91;130&#93;</a></sup> inflation was down to 8.6% from a high of 18%, but unemployment was over 3&#160;million for the first time since the 1930s.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">&#91;131&#93;</a></sup> By 1983, overall economic growth was stronger, and inflation and mortgage rates had fallen to their lowest levels in 13 years, although manufacturing employment as a share of total employment fell to just over 30%,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERowthornWells1987234_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERowthornWells1987234-136">&#91;132&#93;</a></sup> with total unemployment remaining high, peaking at 3.3&#160;million in 1984.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">&#91;133&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>During the 1982 Conservative Party Conference, Thatcher said: "We have done more to roll back the frontiers of socialism than any previous Conservative Government."<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">&#91;134&#93;</a></sup> She said at the Party Conference the following year that the British people had completely rejected <a href="/wiki/State_socialism" title="State socialism">state socialism</a> and understood "the state has no source of money other than money which people earn themselves [...] There is no such thing as public money; there is only taxpayers\' money."<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>By 1987, unemployment was falling, the economy was stable and strong and inflation was low. Opinion polls showed a comfortable Conservative lead, and <a href="/wiki/1987_United_Kingdom_local_elections" title="1987 United Kingdom local elections">local council election</a> results had also been successful, prompting Thatcher to call a general election for 11 June that year, despite the deadline for an election still being 12 months away. The <a href="/wiki/1987_United_Kingdom_general_election" title="1987 United Kingdom general election">election</a> saw Thatcher re-elected for a third successive term.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">&#91;136&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher had been firmly opposed to British membership of the <a href="/wiki/Exchange_Rate_Mechanism" class="mw-redirect" title="Exchange Rate Mechanism">Exchange Rate Mechanism</a> (ERM, a precursor to <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_and_Monetary_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="European Economic and Monetary Union">European Economic and Monetary Union</a>), believing that it would constrain the British economy,<sup id="cite_ref-ecc_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ecc-141">&#91;137&#93;</a></sup> despite the urging of both Chancellor of the Exchequer <a href="/wiki/Nigel_Lawson" title="Nigel Lawson">Nigel Lawson</a> and Foreign Secretary Geoffrey Howe;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThatcher1993712_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThatcher1993712-142">&#91;138&#93;</a></sup> in October 1990 she was persuaded by <a href="/wiki/John_Major" title="John Major">John Major</a>, Lawson\'s successor as Chancellor, to join the ERM at what proved to be too high a rate.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMarr2007484_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarr2007484-143">&#91;139&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher reformed local government taxes by replacing <a href="/wiki/Rates_(tax)" title="Rates (tax)">domestic rates</a> (a tax based on the nominal rental value of a home) with the <a href="/wiki/Poll_tax_(Great_Britain)" title="Poll tax (Great Britain)">Community Charge</a> (or poll tax) in which the same amount was charged to each adult resident.<sup id="cite_ref-polltax_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-polltax-144">&#91;140&#93;</a></sup> The new tax was introduced in Scotland in 1989 and in England and Wales the following year,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReitan200387\xe2\x80\x9388_145-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReitan200387\xe2\x80\x9388-145">&#91;141&#93;</a></sup> and proved to be among the most unpopular policies of her premiership.<sup id="cite_ref-polltax_144-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-polltax-144">&#91;140&#93;</a></sup> Public disquiet culminated in a 70,000 to 200,000-strong<sup id="cite_ref-trafalgarsq_num_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-trafalgarsq_num-146">&#91;142&#93;</a></sup> demonstration in London in March 1990; the demonstration around <a href="/wiki/Trafalgar_Square" title="Trafalgar Square">Trafalgar Square</a> deteriorated into <a href="/wiki/Poll_tax_riots" title="Poll tax riots">riots</a>, leaving 113 people injured and 340 under arrest.<sup id="cite_ref-otd_pt_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-otd_pt-147">&#91;143&#93;</a></sup> The Community Charge was abolished in 1991 by her successor, John Major.<sup id="cite_ref-otd_pt_147-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-otd_pt-147">&#91;143&#93;</a></sup> It has since transpired that Thatcher herself had failed to register for the tax, and was threatened with financial penalties if she did not return her form.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">&#91;144&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Industrial_relations">Industrial relations</span></h4>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/GCHQ_trade_union_ban" title="GCHQ trade union ban">GCHQ trade union ban</a> and <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Civil_Service_Unions_v_Minister_for_the_Civil_Service" title="Council of Civil Service Unions v Minister for the Civil Service">the GCHQ case</a></div>\n<div class="quotebox pullquote floatright" style="width:25em; ; background-color: whitesmoke;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1012376600"/>\n<div class="quotebox-title" style="background-color: whitesmoke;">"Enemy Within" speech</div>\n<div class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style=""><q>We had to fight the enemy without in the Falklands. We always have to be aware of the enemy within, which is much more difficult to fight and more dangerous to liberty.</q></div>\n<p><cite class="right-aligned" style="">Thatcher on the ongoing miners\' dispute in 1984</cite>\n</p>\n</div>\n<p>Thatcher believed that the <a href="/wiki/Trade_unions_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Trade unions in the United Kingdom">trade unions</a> were harmful to both ordinary trade unionists and the public.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell2011a89\xe2\x80\x9390_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell2011a89\xe2\x80\x9390-149">&#91;145&#93;</a></sup> She was committed to reducing the power of the unions, whose leadership she accused of undermining parliamentary democracy and economic performance through strike action.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThatcher199397\xe2\x80\x9398,_339\xe2\x80\x93340_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThatcher199397\xe2\x80\x9398,_339\xe2\x80\x93340-150">&#91;146&#93;</a></sup> Several unions launched strikes in response to legislation introduced to limit their power, but resistance eventually collapsed.<sup id="cite_ref-thatcher-cw_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thatcher-cw-151">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup> Only 39% of union members voted Labour in the 1983 general election.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup> According to the BBC in 2004, Thatcher "managed to destroy the power of the trade unions for almost a generation".<sup id="cite_ref-bbcstrike_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbcstrike-153">&#91;149&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/UK_miners%27_strike_(1984%E2%80%9385)" title="UK miners&#39; strike (1984\xe2\x80\x9385)">miners\' strike of 1984\xe2\x80\x9385</a> was the biggest and most devastating confrontation between the unions and the government under Thatcher.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">&#91;150&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In March 1984, the <a href="/wiki/National_Coal_Board" title="National Coal Board">National Coal Board</a> (NCB) proposed to close 20 of the 174&#160;state-owned mines and cut 20,000&#160;jobs out of 187,000.<sup id="cite_ref-Glass_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Glass-155">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Black_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Black-156">&#91;152&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-pits-closed_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pits-closed-157">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup> Two-thirds of the country\'s miners, led by the <a href="/wiki/National_Union_of_Mineworkers_(Great_Britain)" title="National Union of Mineworkers (Great Britain)">National Union of Mineworkers</a> (NUM) under <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Scargill" title="Arthur Scargill">Arthur Scargill</a>, downed tools in protest.<sup id="cite_ref-Glass_155-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Glass-155">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-thatcher-num_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thatcher-num-158">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Jones_159-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jones-159">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup> However, Scargill refused to hold a ballot on the strike,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAdeneyLloyd198888\xe2\x80\x9389_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAdeneyLloyd198888\xe2\x80\x9389-160">&#91;156&#93;</a></sup> having previously lost three ballots on a national strike (in January and October 1982, and March 1983).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAdeneyLloyd1988169_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAdeneyLloyd1988169-161">&#91;157&#93;</a></sup> This led to the strike being declared illegal by the <a href="/wiki/High_Court_of_Justice" title="High Court of Justice">High Court of Justice</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAdeneyLloyd1988170_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAdeneyLloyd1988170-162">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">&#91;159&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher refused to meet the union\'s demands and compared the miners\' dispute to the <a href="/wiki/Falklands_War" title="Falklands War">Falklands War</a>, declaring in a speech in 1984: "We had to fight the enemy without in the Falklands. We always have to be aware of the enemy within, which is much more difficult to fight and more dangerous to liberty."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhabaz2006226_164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhabaz2006226-164">&#91;160&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher\'s opponents presented her words as indicating contempt for the working class, and have been employed in criticism of her ever since.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMoore2015164_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMoore2015164-165">&#91;161&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>After a year out on strike, in March 1985 the NUM leadership conceded without a deal. The cost to the economy was estimated to be at least \xc2\xa31.5&#160;billion, and the strike was blamed for much of the <a href="/wiki/Pound_sterling" title="Pound sterling">pound</a>\'s fall against the <a href="/wiki/United_States_dollar" title="United States dollar">US dollar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Harper_166-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harper-166">&#91;162&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher reflected on the end of the strike in her statement that "if anyone has won" it was "the miners who stayed at work" and all those "that have kept Britain going".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMoore2015178_167-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMoore2015178-167">&#91;163&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The government closed 25&#160;unprofitable coal mines in 1985, and by 1992 a total of 97 mines had been closed;<sup id="cite_ref-pits-closed_157-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pits-closed-157">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup> those that remained were privatised in 1994.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">&#91;164&#93;</a></sup> The resulting closure of 150&#160;coal mines, some of which were not losing money, resulted in the loss of tens of thousands of jobs and had the effect of devastating entire communities.<sup id="cite_ref-pits-closed_157-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pits-closed-157">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup> Strikes had helped bring down Heath\'s government, and Thatcher was determined to succeed where he had failed. Her strategy of preparing fuel stocks, appointing hardliner <a href="/wiki/Ian_MacGregor" title="Ian MacGregor">Ian MacGregor</a> as NCB leader, and ensuring that police were adequately trained and equipped with riot gear, contributed to her triumph over the striking miners.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMarr2007411_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarr2007411-169">&#91;165&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The number of stoppages across the UK peaked at 4,583 in 1979, when more than 29&#160;million working days had been lost. In 1984, the year of the miners\' strike, there were 1,221, resulting in the loss of more than 27&#160;million working days. Stoppages then fell steadily throughout the rest of Thatcher\'s premiership; in 1990 there were 630 and fewer than 2&#160;million working days lost, and they continued to fall thereafter.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEButlerButler1994375_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEButlerButler1994375-170">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher\'s tenure also witnessed a sharp decline in trade union density, with the percentage of workers belonging to a trade union falling from 57.3% in 1979 to 49.5% in 1985.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELaybourn1992208_171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELaybourn1992208-171">&#91;167&#93;</a></sup> In 1979 up until Thatcher\'s final year in office, trade union membership also fell, from 13.5&#160;million in 1979 to fewer than 10&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarrell1994127_172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarrell1994127-172">&#91;168&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Privatisation">Privatisation</span></h4>\n<p>The policy of <a href="/wiki/Privatisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Privatisation">privatisation</a> has been called "a crucial ingredient of Thatcherism".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESeldonCollings200027_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESeldonCollings200027-173">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup> After the 1983 election the sale of state utilities accelerated;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFeigenbaumHenigHamnett199871_174-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFeigenbaumHenigHamnett199871-174">&#91;170&#93;</a></sup> more than \xc2\xa329&#160;billion was raised from the sale of nationalised industries, and another \xc2\xa318&#160;billion from the sale of council houses.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMarr2007428_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarr2007428-175">&#91;171&#93;</a></sup> The process of privatisation, especially the preparation of nationalised industries for privatisation, was associated with marked improvements in performance, particularly in terms of <a href="/wiki/Workforce_productivity" title="Workforce productivity">labour productivity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEParkerMartin1995_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEParkerMartin1995-176">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Some of the privatised industries, including gas, <a href="/wiki/Water_privatisation_in_England_and_Wales" title="Water privatisation in England and Wales">water</a>, and electricity, were <a href="/wiki/Natural_monopoly" title="Natural monopoly">natural monopolies</a> for which privatisation involved little increase in competition. The privatised industries that demonstrated improvement sometimes did so while still under state ownership. <a href="/wiki/British_Steel_Corporation" class="mw-redirect" title="British Steel Corporation">British Steel Corporation</a> had made great gains in profitability while still a nationalised industry under the government-appointed MacGregor chairmanship, which faced down trade-union opposition to close plants and halve the workforce.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup> Regulation was also significantly expanded to compensate for the loss of direct government control, with the foundation of regulatory bodies such as <a href="/wiki/Oftel" title="Oftel">Oftel</a> (<a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_Act_1984" title="Telecommunications Act 1984">1984</a>), <a href="/wiki/Ofgas" class="mw-redirect" title="Ofgas">Ofgas</a> (<a href="/wiki/Gas_Act_1986" title="Gas Act 1986">1986</a>), and the <a href="/wiki/National_Rivers_Authority" title="National Rivers Authority">National Rivers Authority</a> (<a href="/wiki/Water_Act_1989" title="Water Act 1989">1989</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVeljanovski1990291\xe2\x80\x93304_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVeljanovski1990291\xe2\x80\x93304-178">&#91;174&#93;</a></sup> There was no clear pattern to the degree of competition, regulation, and performance among the privatised industries.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEParkerMartin1995_176-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEParkerMartin1995-176">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In most cases, privatisation benefited consumers in terms of lower prices and improved efficiency, but results overall have been mixed.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcAleese2004169\xe2\x80\x9370_179-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcAleese2004169\xe2\x80\x9370-179">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup> Not all privatised companies have had successful share price trajectories in the longer term.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">&#91;176&#93;</a></sup> A 2010 review by the IEA states: "it does seem to be the case that once competition and/or effective regulation was introduced, performance improved markedly [...] But I hasten to emphasise again that the literature is not unanimous."<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">&#91;177&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher always resisted <a href="/wiki/Privatisation_of_British_Rail" title="Privatisation of British Rail">privatising British Rail</a> and was said to have told Transport Secretary <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_Ridley,_Baron_Ridley_of_Liddesdale" title="Nicholas Ridley, Baron Ridley of Liddesdale">Nicholas Ridley</a>: "Railway privatisation will be the <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Waterloo#Noun" class="extiw" title="wikt:Waterloo">Waterloo</a> of this government. Please never mention the railways to me again." Shortly before her resignation in 1990, she accepted the arguments for privatisation, which her successor John Major implemented in 1994.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMarr2007495_182-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarr2007495-182">&#91;178&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The privatisation of public assets was combined with <a href="/wiki/Deregulation#United_Kingdom" title="Deregulation">financial deregulation</a> in an attempt to fuel economic growth. Chancellor Geoffrey Howe abolished the UK\'s exchange controls in 1979,<sup id="cite_ref-Robertson_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Robertson-183">&#91;179&#93;</a></sup> which allowed more capital to be invested in foreign markets, and the <a href="/wiki/Big_Bang_(financial_markets)" title="Big Bang (financial markets)">Big Bang</a> of 1986 removed many restrictions on the <a href="/wiki/London_Stock_Exchange" title="London Stock Exchange">London Stock Exchange</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Robertson_183-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Robertson-183">&#91;179&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Northern_Ireland">Northern Ireland</span></h4>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Margaret_Thatcher_on_a_visit_to_Northern_Ireland.jpg" class="image"><img alt="photograph" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Margaret_Thatcher_on_a_visit_to_Northern_Ireland.jpg/220px-Margaret_Thatcher_on_a_visit_to_Northern_Ireland.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="163" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Margaret_Thatcher_on_a_visit_to_Northern_Ireland.jpg/330px-Margaret_Thatcher_on_a_visit_to_Northern_Ireland.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Margaret_Thatcher_on_a_visit_to_Northern_Ireland.jpg/440px-Margaret_Thatcher_on_a_visit_to_Northern_Ireland.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2596" data-file-height="1924" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Margaret_Thatcher_on_a_visit_to_Northern_Ireland.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Margaret and <a href="/wiki/Denis_Thatcher" title="Denis Thatcher">Denis Thatcher</a> on a visit to Northern Ireland in late 1982</div></div></div>\n<p>In 1980 and 1981, <a href="/wiki/Provisional_Irish_Republican_Army" title="Provisional Irish Republican Army">Provisional Irish Republican Army</a> (PIRA) and <a href="/wiki/Irish_National_Liberation_Army" title="Irish National Liberation Army">Irish National Liberation Army</a> (INLA) prisoners in Northern Ireland\'s <a href="/wiki/HM_Prison_Maze" title="HM Prison Maze">Maze Prison</a> carried out <a href="/wiki/1981_Irish_hunger_strike" title="1981 Irish hunger strike">hunger strikes</a> in an effort to regain the status of political prisoners that had been removed in 1976 by the preceding Labour government.<sup id="cite_ref-strike_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-strike-184">&#91;180&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bobby_Sands" title="Bobby Sands">Bobby Sands</a> began the 1981 strike, saying that he would fast until death unless prison inmates won concessions over their living conditions.<sup id="cite_ref-strike_184-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-strike-184">&#91;180&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher refused to countenance a return to political status for the prisoners, having declared "Crime is crime is crime; it is not political",<sup id="cite_ref-strike_184-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-strike-184">&#91;180&#93;</a></sup> Nevertheless, the British government privately contacted republican leaders in a bid to bring the hunger strikes to an end.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">&#91;181&#93;</a></sup> After the deaths of Sands and nine others, the strike ended. Some rights were restored to paramilitary prisoners, but not official recognition of political status.<sup id="cite_ref-CAIN-hs_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CAIN-hs-186">&#91;182&#93;</a></sup> Violence in Northern Ireland escalated significantly during the hunger strikes.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEnglish2005207\xe2\x80\x9308_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEnglish2005207\xe2\x80\x9308-187">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher narrowly escaped injury in an IRA <a href="/wiki/Brighton_hotel_bombing" title="Brighton hotel bombing">assassination attempt</a> at a Brighton hotel early in the morning on 12 October 1984.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc-bomb_188-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-bomb-188">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup> Five people were killed, including the wife of minister <a href="/wiki/John_Wakeham" title="John Wakeham">John Wakeham</a>. Thatcher was staying at the hotel to prepare for the Conservative Party conference, which she insisted should open as scheduled the following day.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc-bomb_188-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-bomb-188">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup> She delivered her speech as planned,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThatcher1993379\xe2\x80\x93383_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThatcher1993379\xe2\x80\x93383-189">&#91;185&#93;</a></sup> though rewritten from her original draft,<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">&#91;186&#93;</a></sup> in a move that was widely supported across the political spectrum and enhanced her popularity with the public.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELanoueHeadrick1998_191-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELanoueHeadrick1998-191">&#91;187&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>On 6 November 1981, Thatcher and Irish Taoiseach <a href="/wiki/Garret_FitzGerald" title="Garret FitzGerald">Garret FitzGerald</a> had established the Anglo-Irish Inter-Governmental Council, a forum for meetings between the two governments.<sup id="cite_ref-CAIN-hs_186-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CAIN-hs-186">&#91;182&#93;</a></sup> On 15 November 1985, Thatcher and FitzGerald signed the Hillsborough <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Irish_Agreement" title="Anglo-Irish Agreement">Anglo-Irish Agreement</a>, which marked the first time a British government had given the Republic of Ireland an advisory role in the governance of Northern Ireland. In protest, the <a href="/wiki/Ulster_Says_No" title="Ulster Says No">Ulster Says No</a> movement led by <a href="/wiki/Ian_Paisley" title="Ian Paisley">Ian Paisley</a> attracted 100,000 to a rally in Belfast,<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">&#91;188&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ian_Gow" title="Ian Gow">Ian Gow</a>, later assassinated by the PIRA, resigned as <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_State" title="Minister of State">Minister of State</a> in the <a href="/wiki/HM_Treasury" title="HM Treasury">HM Treasury</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMoloney2002336_194-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMoloney2002336-194">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup> and all 15 Unionist MPs resigned their parliamentary seats; only one was not returned in the subsequent <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_Kingdom_by-elections_(1979%E2%80%932010)" title="List of United Kingdom by-elections (1979\xe2\x80\x932010)">by-elections</a> on 23 January 1986.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECochrane1997143_195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECochrane1997143-195">&#91;191&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">Environment</span></h3>\n<p>Thatcher supported an active <a href="/wiki/Climate_protection" class="mw-redirect" title="Climate protection">climate protection</a> policy;<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">&#91;nb 5&#93;</a></sup> she was instrumental in the passing of the <a href="/wiki/Environmental_Protection_Act_1990" title="Environmental Protection Act 1990">Environmental Protection Act 1990</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETewdwr-Jones200347_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETewdwr-Jones200347-198">&#91;193&#93;</a></sup> the founding of the <a href="/wiki/Hadley_Centre_for_Climate_Prediction_and_Research" class="mw-redirect" title="Hadley Centre for Climate Prediction and Research">Hadley Centre for Climate Research and Prediction</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">&#91;194&#93;</a></sup> the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Intergovernmental_Panel_on_Climate_Change" title="Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change">Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Harrabin_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harrabin-200">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup> and the ratification of the <a href="/wiki/Montreal_Protocol" title="Montreal Protocol">Montreal Protocol</a> on preserving the <a href="/wiki/Ozone_layer" title="Ozone layer">ozone</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">&#91;196&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher helped to put <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a>, <a href="/wiki/Acid_rain" title="Acid rain">acid rain</a> and general pollution in the British mainstream in the late 1980s,<sup id="cite_ref-Harrabin_200-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Harrabin-200">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell2011a642_202-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell2011a642-202">&#91;197&#93;</a></sup> calling for a global treaty on climate change in 1989.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">&#91;198&#93;</a></sup> Her speeches included one to the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Society" title="Royal Society">Royal Society</a> in 1988,<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">&#91;199&#93;</a></sup> followed by another to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly" title="United Nations General Assembly">UN General Assembly</a> in 1989.\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_affairs">Foreign affairs</span></h3>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Thatcher_at_Oval_Office_desk_with_Carter.jpg" class="image"><img alt="photograph of Thatcher and Carter" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Thatcher_at_Oval_Office_desk_with_Carter.jpg/200px-Thatcher_at_Oval_Office_desk_with_Carter.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="141" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Thatcher_at_Oval_Office_desk_with_Carter.jpg/300px-Thatcher_at_Oval_Office_desk_with_Carter.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Thatcher_at_Oval_Office_desk_with_Carter.jpg/400px-Thatcher_at_Oval_Office_desk_with_Carter.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1002" data-file-height="705" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Thatcher with President <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Carter" title="Jimmy Carter">Jimmy Carter</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Oval_Office" title="Oval Office">Oval Office</a>, 1979</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:President_Ronald_Reagan_and_Prime_Minister_Margaret_Thatcher_of_the_United_Kingdom.jpg" class="image"><img alt="photograph of Thatcher and Reagan" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/President_Ronald_Reagan_and_Prime_Minister_Margaret_Thatcher_of_the_United_Kingdom.jpg/200px-President_Ronald_Reagan_and_Prime_Minister_Margaret_Thatcher_of_the_United_Kingdom.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/President_Ronald_Reagan_and_Prime_Minister_Margaret_Thatcher_of_the_United_Kingdom.jpg/300px-President_Ronald_Reagan_and_Prime_Minister_Margaret_Thatcher_of_the_United_Kingdom.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/President_Ronald_Reagan_and_Prime_Minister_Margaret_Thatcher_of_the_United_Kingdom.jpg/400px-President_Ronald_Reagan_and_Prime_Minister_Margaret_Thatcher_of_the_United_Kingdom.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="2651" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Thatcher with President <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> in the Oval Office, 1988</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Thatcher_and_Bush_-_1990_-_P14935-18A.jpg" class="image"><img alt="photograph of Thatcher and Bush" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Thatcher_and_Bush_-_1990_-_P14935-18A.jpg/200px-Thatcher_and_Bush_-_1990_-_P14935-18A.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="134" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Thatcher_and_Bush_-_1990_-_P14935-18A.jpg/300px-Thatcher_and_Bush_-_1990_-_P14935-18A.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Thatcher_and_Bush_-_1990_-_P14935-18A.jpg/400px-Thatcher_and_Bush_-_1990_-_P14935-18A.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1239" data-file-height="831" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Thatcher with President <a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">George H. W. Bush</a> in <a href="/wiki/Aspen,_Colorado" title="Aspen, Colorado">Aspen, Colorado</a>, 1990</div></div></div></div></div>\n<p>Thatcher appointed Lord Carrington, an ennobled member of the party and former <a href="/wiki/Secretary_of_State_for_Defence" title="Secretary of State for Defence">Secretary of State for Defence</a>, to run the <a href="/wiki/Foreign_Office" class="mw-redirect" title="Foreign Office">Foreign Office</a> in 1979.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESkedCook1993364\xe2\x80\x93422_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESkedCook1993364\xe2\x80\x93422-205">&#91;200&#93;</a></sup> Although considered a "wet", he avoided domestic affairs and got along well with Thatcher. One issue was what to do with <a href="/wiki/Rhodesia" title="Rhodesia">Rhodesia</a>, where the white-minority had determined to rule the prosperous, black-majority breakaway colony in the face of overwhelming international criticism. With the 1975 <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese</a> collapse in the continent, South Africa (which had been Rhodesia\'s chief supporter) realised that their ally was a liability; black rule was inevitable, and the Thatcher government brokered a peaceful solution to end the <a href="/wiki/Rhodesian_Bush_War" title="Rhodesian Bush War">Rhodesian Bush War</a> in December 1979 via the <a href="/wiki/Lancaster_House_Agreement" title="Lancaster House Agreement">Lancaster House Agreement</a>. The conference at Lancaster was attended by Rhodesian prime minister <a href="/wiki/Ian_Smith" title="Ian Smith">Ian Smith</a>, as well as by the key black leaders: <a href="/wiki/Muzorewa" class="mw-redirect" title="Muzorewa">Muzorewa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mugabe" class="mw-redirect" title="Mugabe">Mugabe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joshua_Nkomo" title="Joshua Nkomo">Nkomo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tongogara" class="mw-redirect" title="Tongogara">Tongogara</a>. The end result was the new Zimbabwean nation under black rule in 1980.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewis1980Soames1980_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewis1980Soames1980-206">&#91;201&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Cold_War">Cold War</span></h4>\n<p>Thatcher\'s first foreign-policy crisis came with the 1979 <a href="/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Afghanistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet invasion of Afghanistan">Soviet invasion of Afghanistan</a>. She condemned the invasion, said it showed the bankruptcy of a <a href="/wiki/D%C3%A9tente" title="D\xc3\xa9tente">d\xc3\xa9tente</a> policy, and helped convince some British athletes to boycott the <a href="/wiki/1980_Moscow_Olympics" class="mw-redirect" title="1980 Moscow Olympics">1980 Moscow Olympics</a>. She gave weak support to US president Jimmy Carter who tried to punish the USSR with economic sanctions. Britain\'s economic situation was precarious, and most of NATO was reluctant to cut trade ties.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELahey2013_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELahey2013-207">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher nevertheless gave the go-ahead for <a href="/wiki/Whitehall" title="Whitehall">Whitehall</a> to approve <a href="/wiki/MI6" class="mw-redirect" title="MI6">MI6</a> (along with the SAS) to undertake "disruptive action" in Afghanistan.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDorril2002&lt;span_class=&quot;plainlinks&quot;&gt;&#91;httpsarchiveorgdetailsmi6insidecovertw00dorrpage752_752&amp;nbsp;&lt;span_style=&quot;position:relative;_top:_-2px;&quot;&gt;&#91;&#91;File:Closed_Access_logo_transparent.svg&#124;9px&#124;link=Paywall&#124;closed_access_publication_\xe2\x80\x93_behind_paywall&#124;alt=closed_access&#93;&#93;&lt;/span&gt;_&#93;&lt;/span&gt;_208-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDorril2002&lt;span_class=&quot;plainlinks&quot;&gt;[httpsarchiveorgdetailsmi6insidecovertw00dorrpage752_752&amp;nbsp;&lt;span_style=&quot;position:relative;_top:_-2px;&quot;&gt;[[File:Closed_Access_logo_transparent.svg|9px|link=Paywall|closed_access_publication_\xe2\x80\x93_behind_paywall|alt=closed_access]]&lt;/span&gt;_]&lt;/span&gt;-208">&#91;203&#93;</a></sup> As well working with the CIA in <a href="/wiki/Operation_Cyclone" title="Operation Cyclone">Operation Cyclone</a>, they also supplied weapons, training and intelligence to the <i><a href="/wiki/Mujaheddin" class="mw-redirect" title="Mujaheddin">mujaheddin</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECormac2018233\xe2\x80\x9336_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECormac2018233\xe2\x80\x9336-209">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <i><a href="/wiki/Financial_Times" title="Financial Times">Financial Times</a></i> reported in 2011 that her government had secretly supplied <a href="/wiki/Ba%27athist_Iraq" title="Ba&#39;athist Iraq">Ba\'athist Iraq</a> under <a href="/wiki/Saddam_Hussein" title="Saddam Hussein">Saddam Hussein</a> with <a href="/wiki/British_support_for_Iraq_during_the_Iran%E2%80%93Iraq_war" title="British support for Iraq during the Iran\xe2\x80\x93Iraq war">"non-lethal" military equipment since 1981</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thatcher_Hussein_secret_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thatcher_Hussein_secret-210">&#91;205&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Having withdrawn formal recognition from the <a href="/wiki/Pol_Pot_regime" class="mw-redirect" title="Pol Pot regime">Pol Pot regime</a> in 1979,<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup> the Thatcher government backed the <a href="/wiki/Khmer_Rouge" title="Khmer Rouge">Khmer Rouge</a> keeping their UN seat after they were ousted from power in Cambodia by the <a href="/wiki/Cambodian%E2%80%93Vietnamese_War" title="Cambodian\xe2\x80\x93Vietnamese War">Cambodian\xe2\x80\x93Vietnamese War</a>. Although Thatcher denied it at the time,<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">&#91;208&#93;</a></sup> it was revealed in 1991 that, while not directly training any Khmer Rouge,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENeville201620_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENeville201620-214">&#91;209&#93;</a></sup> from 1983 the <a href="/wiki/Special_Air_Service" title="Special Air Service">Special Air Service</a> (SAS) was sent to secretly train "the armed forces of the <a href="/wiki/Coalition_Government_of_Democratic_Kampuchea" title="Coalition Government of Democratic Kampuchea">Cambodian non-communist resistance</a>" that remained loyal to Prince <a href="/wiki/Norodom_Sihanouk" title="Norodom Sihanouk">Norodom Sihanouk</a> and his former prime minister <a href="/wiki/Son_Sann" title="Son Sann">Son Sann</a> in the fight against the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_Kampuchea" title="People&#39;s Republic of Kampuchea">Vietnamese-backed puppet regime</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">&#91;210&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">&#91;211&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher was one of the first Western leaders to respond warmly to reformist Soviet leader <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev" title="Mikhail Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a>. Following Reagan\xe2\x80\x93Gorbachev summit meetings and reforms enacted by Gorbachev in the USSR, she declared in November 1988 that "We\'re not in a Cold War now", but rather in a "new relationship much wider than the Cold War ever was".<sup id="cite_ref-reforms1988_217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reforms1988-217">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup> She went on a state visit to the Soviet Union in 1984 and met with Gorbachev and Council of Ministers chairman <a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Ryzhkov" title="Nikolai Ryzhkov">Nikolai Ryzhkov</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZemcovFarrar1989138_218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZemcovFarrar1989138-218">&#91;213&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Ties_with_the_US">Ties with the US</span></h4>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Reagan-Thatcher_cabinet_talks.jpg" class="image"><img alt="photograph" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Reagan-Thatcher_cabinet_talks.jpg/220px-Reagan-Thatcher_cabinet_talks.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Reagan-Thatcher_cabinet_talks.jpg/330px-Reagan-Thatcher_cabinet_talks.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Reagan-Thatcher_cabinet_talks.jpg/440px-Reagan-Thatcher_cabinet_talks.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2033" data-file-height="1350" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Reagan-Thatcher_cabinet_talks.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Thatcher and her cabinet meeting with the <a href="/wiki/Reagan_cabinet" class="mw-redirect" title="Reagan cabinet">Reagan cabinet</a> in the <a href="/wiki/White_House_Cabinet_Room" class="mw-redirect" title="White House Cabinet Room">White House Cabinet Room</a>, 1981</div></div></div>\n<p>Despite opposite personalities, Thatcher bonded quickly with US president <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">&#91;nb 6&#93;</a></sup> She gave strong support to the <a href="/wiki/Reagan_Doctrine" title="Reagan Doctrine">Reagan administration\'s Cold War policies</a> based on their shared <a href="/wiki/Anti-communism" title="Anti-communism">distrust of communism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-thatcher-cw_151-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thatcher-cw-151">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup> A sharp disagreement came in 1983 when Reagan did not consult with her on the <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Grenada" class="mw-redirect" title="Invasion of Grenada">invasion of Grenada</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams2001_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams2001-220">&#91;214&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>During her first year as prime minister she supported <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>\'s decision to deploy US nuclear <a href="/wiki/BGM-109G_Ground_Launched_Cruise_Missile" title="BGM-109G Ground Launched Cruise Missile">cruise</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pershing_II" title="Pershing II">Pershing II</a> missiles in Western Europe,<sup id="cite_ref-thatcher-cw_151-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thatcher-cw-151">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup> permitting the US to station more than 160&#160;cruise missiles at <a href="/wiki/RAF_Greenham_Common" title="RAF Greenham Common">RAF Greenham Common</a>, starting in November 1983 and triggering mass protests by the <a href="/wiki/Campaign_for_Nuclear_Disarmament" title="Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament">Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-thatcher-cw_151-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thatcher-cw-151">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup> She bought the <a href="/wiki/Trident_nuclear_missile" class="mw-redirect" title="Trident nuclear missile">Trident nuclear missile</a> submarine system from the US to replace Polaris, tripling the UK\'s nuclear forces<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup> at an eventual cost of more than \xc2\xa312&#160;billion (at 1996\xe2\x80\x9397 prices).<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">&#91;217&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher\'s preference for defence ties with the US was demonstrated in the <a href="/wiki/Westland_affair" title="Westland affair">Westland affair</a> of 1985\xe2\x80\x9386, when she acted with colleagues to allow the struggling helicopter manufacturer <a href="/wiki/Westland_Helicopters" title="Westland Helicopters">Westland</a> to refuse a takeover offer from the Italian firm <a href="/wiki/Agusta" title="Agusta">Agusta</a> in favour of the management\'s preferred option, a link with <a href="/wiki/Sikorsky_Aircraft" title="Sikorsky Aircraft">Sikorsky Aircraft</a>. Defence Secretary <a href="/wiki/Michael_Heseltine" title="Michael Heseltine">Michael Heseltine</a>, who had supported the Agusta deal, resigned from the government in protest.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMarr2007419_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarr2007419-224">&#91;218&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In April 1986 she permitted US <a href="/wiki/General_Dynamics_F-111_Aardvark" title="General Dynamics F-111 Aardvark">F-111s</a> to use <a href="/wiki/Royal_Air_Force" title="Royal Air Force">Royal Air Force</a> bases for the <a href="/wiki/1986_United_States_bombing_of_Libya" title="1986 United States bombing of Libya">bombing of Libya</a> in retaliation for the alleged <a href="/wiki/West_Berlin_discotheque_bombing" title="West Berlin discotheque bombing">Libyan bombing of a Berlin discoth\xc3\xa8que</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Cannon_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cannon-225">&#91;219&#93;</a></sup> citing the right of self-defence under <a href="/wiki/Chapter_VII_of_the_United_Nations_Charter" title="Chapter VII of the United Nations Charter">Article 51 of the UN Charter</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">&#91;220&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">&#91;nb 7&#93;</a></sup> Polls suggested that fewer than one in three British citizens approved of her decision.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">&#91;222&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher was in the US on a state visit when Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Kuwait" title="Invasion of Kuwait">invaded Kuwait</a> in August 1990.<sup id="cite_ref-gw-pbs_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gw-pbs-230">&#91;223&#93;</a></sup> During her talks with President <a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">George H. W. Bush</a>, who succeeded Reagan in 1989, she recommended intervention,<sup id="cite_ref-gw-pbs_230-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gw-pbs-230">&#91;223&#93;</a></sup> and put pressure on Bush to deploy troops in the Middle East to drive the <a href="/wiki/Iraqi_Army" title="Iraqi Army">Iraqi Army</a> out of Kuwait.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">&#91;224&#93;</a></sup> Bush was apprehensive about the plan, prompting Thatcher to remark to him during a telephone conversation: "This was no time to go wobbly!"<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher\'s government supplied military forces to the international coalition in the build-up to the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">Gulf War</a>, but she had resigned by the time hostilities began on 17 January 1991.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAitken2013600\xe2\x80\x93601_234-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAitken2013600\xe2\x80\x93601-234">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-grice_235-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grice-235">&#91;228&#93;</a></sup> She applauded the coalition victory on the backbenches, while warning that "the victories of peace will take longer than the battles of war".<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup> It was disclosed in 2017 that Thatcher had suggested threatening Saddam with <a href="/wiki/Chemical_weapon" title="Chemical weapon">chemical weapons</a> after the invasion of Kuwait.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">&#91;230&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">&#91;231&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Crisis_in_the_Falklands">Crisis in the Falklands</span></h4>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Rejoice_(Margaret_Thatcher)" title="Rejoice (Margaret Thatcher)">"Rejoice"</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gould%E2%80%93Thatcher_exchange" title="Gould\xe2\x80\x93Thatcher exchange">the Gould exchange</a></div>\n<p>On 2 April 1982 the ruling <a href="/wiki/National_Reorganization_Process" title="National Reorganization Process">military junta in Argentina</a> ordered the invasion of the British possessions of the <a href="/wiki/Falkland_Islands" title="Falkland Islands">Falkland Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_Georgia_and_the_South_Sandwich_Islands" title="South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands">South Georgia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Events_leading_to_the_Falklands_War" title="Events leading to the Falklands War">triggering the Falklands War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESmith198921_239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmith198921-239">&#91;232&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Falkland_Islands" title="Occupation of the Falkland Islands">subsequent crisis</a> was "a defining moment of &#91;Thatcher\'s&#93; premiership".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJackling2005230_240-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJackling2005230-240">&#91;233&#93;</a></sup> At the suggestion of Harold Macmillan and <a href="/wiki/Robert_Armstrong,_Baron_Armstrong_of_Ilminster" title="Robert Armstrong, Baron Armstrong of Ilminster">Robert Armstrong</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJackling2005230_240-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJackling2005230-240">&#91;233&#93;</a></sup> she set up and chaired a small <a href="/wiki/War_cabinet#Falklands_War" title="War cabinet">War Cabinet</a> (formally called ODSA, Overseas and Defence committee, South Atlantic) to oversee the conduct of the war,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHastingsJenkins198380\xe2\x80\x9381_241-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHastingsJenkins198380\xe2\x80\x9381-241">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup> which by 5\xe2\x80\x936 April had authorised and dispatched a <a href="/wiki/British_naval_forces_in_the_Falklands_War" title="British naval forces in the Falklands War">naval task force</a> to retake the islands.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHastingsJenkins198395_242-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHastingsJenkins198395-242">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup> Argentina <a href="/wiki/Argentine_surrender_in_the_Falklands_War" title="Argentine surrender in the Falklands War">surrendered on 14 June</a> and <i>Operation Corporate</i> was hailed a success, notwithstanding the deaths of 255&#160;British servicemen and 3&#160;Falkland Islanders. Argentine fatalities totalled 649, half of them after the nuclear-powered submarine <a href="/wiki/HMS_Conqueror_(S48)" title="HMS Conqueror (S48)">HMS&#160;<i>Conqueror</i></a> torpedoed and sank the cruiser <a href="/wiki/ARA_General_Belgrano" title="ARA General Belgrano">ARA&#160;<i>General Belgrano</i></a> on 2 May.<sup id="cite_ref-liberation_243-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-liberation-243">&#91;236&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher was criticised for the neglect of the Falklands\' defence that led to the war, and especially by Labour MP <a href="/wiki/Tam_Dalyell" title="Tam Dalyell">Tam Dalyell</a> in Parliament for the decision to torpedo the <i>General Belgrano</i>, but overall she was considered a highly capable and committed war leader.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHastingsJenkins1983335\xe2\x80\x93336_244-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHastingsJenkins1983335\xe2\x80\x93336-244">&#91;237&#93;</a></sup> The "<a href="/wiki/Falklands_factor" class="mw-redirect" title="Falklands factor">Falklands factor</a>", an economic recovery beginning early in 1982, and a bitterly divided opposition all contributed to Thatcher\'s second election victory in <a href="/wiki/1983_United_Kingdom_general_election" title="1983 United Kingdom general election">1983</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandersWardMarsh1987_245-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandersWardMarsh1987-245">&#91;238&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher frequently referred after the war to the "Falklands spirit";<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">&#91;239&#93;</a></sup> <a href="#CITEREFHastingsJenkins1983">Hastings &amp; Jenkins (1983</a>, p.&#160;329) suggests that this reflected her preference for the streamlined decision-making of her War Cabinet over the painstaking deal-making of peacetime <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_government" class="mw-redirect" title="Cabinet government">cabinet government</a>.\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Negotiating_Hong_Kong">Negotiating Hong Kong</span></h4>\n<p>In September 1982 she visited China to discuss with <a href="/wiki/Deng_Xiaoping" title="Deng Xiaoping">Deng Xiaoping</a> the <a href="/wiki/Sovereignty_of_Hong_Kong" class="mw-redirect" title="Sovereignty of Hong Kong">sovereignty of Hong Kong</a> after 1997. China was the first communist state Thatcher had visited and she was the first British prime minister to visit China. Throughout their meeting, she sought the PRC\'s agreement to a continued British presence in the territory. Deng insisted that the PRC\'s sovereignty on Hong Kong was non-negotiable, but stated his willingness to settle the sovereignty issue with the British government through formal negotiations, and both governments promised to maintain Hong Kong\'s stability and prosperity.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYahuda1996155_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYahuda1996155-247">&#91;240&#93;</a></sup> After the two-year negotiations, Thatcher conceded to the PRC government and signed the <a href="/wiki/Sino-British_Joint_Declaration" title="Sino-British Joint Declaration">Sino-British Joint Declaration</a> in Beijing in 1984, agreeing to hand over Hong Kong\'s sovereignty in 1997.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReitan2003116_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReitan2003116-248">&#91;241&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Apartheid_in_South_Africa">Apartheid in South Africa</span></h4>\n<p>Despite saying that she was in favour of "peaceful negotiations" to end <a href="/wiki/Apartheid" title="Apartheid">apartheid</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">&#91;242&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">&#91;243&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher opposed <a href="/wiki/Disinvestment_from_South_Africa" title="Disinvestment from South Africa">sanctions imposed on South Africa</a> by the Commonwealth and the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> (EEC).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell2011a322_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell2011a322-251">&#91;244&#93;</a></sup> She attempted to preserve trade with South Africa while persuading the government there to abandon apartheid. This included "[c]asting herself as <a href="/wiki/President_Botha" class="mw-redirect" title="President Botha">President Botha</a>\'s candid friend", and inviting him to visit the UK in 1984,<sup id="cite_ref-Hanning_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hanning-252">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup> in spite of the "inevitable demonstrations" against his government.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell2011a325_253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell2011a325-253">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup> Alan Merrydew of the Canadian broadcaster <a href="/wiki/CHAN-DT" title="CHAN-DT">BCTV News</a> asked Thatcher what her response was "to a reported ANC statement that they will target British firms in South Africa?", to which she later replied: "[...] when the ANC says that they will target British companies [...] This shows what a typical terrorist organisation it is. I fought terrorism all my life and if more people fought it, and we were all more successful, we should not have it and I hope that everyone in this hall will think it is right to go on fighting terrorism."<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">&#91;247&#93;</a></sup> During his visit to Britain five months after his release from prison, <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Mandela" title="Nelson Mandela">Nelson Mandela</a> praised Thatcher: "She is an enemy of apartheid [...] We have much to thank her for."<sup id="cite_ref-Hanning_252-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hanning-252">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Europe">Europe</span></h4>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Bruges_speech" title="Bruges speech">Bruges speech</a></div>\n<table class="infobox" style="float: right; clear: right; margin:0 0 1.5em 1.5em"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" class="infobox-above" style="font-size:115%">External video</th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="infobox-subheader" style="font-style: italic">1988 speech to the <a href="/wiki/College_of_Europe" title="College of Europe">College of Europe</a></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="infobox-full-data" style="text-align: left"><img alt="video icon" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Nuvola_apps_kaboodle.svg/16px-Nuvola_apps_kaboodle.svg.png" decoding="async" width="16" height="16" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Nuvola_apps_kaboodle.svg/24px-Nuvola_apps_kaboodle.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Nuvola_apps_kaboodle.svg/32px-Nuvola_apps_kaboodle.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="128" data-file-height="128" /> <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"/><cite class="citation speech cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.margaretthatcher.org/document/113688"><i>Speech to the College of Europe</i> (\'The Bruges Speech\')</a> (Speech) &#8211; via the Margaret Thatcher Foundation.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Speech+to+the+College+of+Europe%3C%2Fi%3E+%28%27The+Bruges+Speech%27%29&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.margaretthatcher.org%2Fdocument%2F113688&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMargaret+Thatcher" class="Z3988"></span><sup id="cite_ref-Bruges_255-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bruges-255">&#91;248&#93;</a></sup></td></tr></tbody></table><p>\nThatcher and her party supported British membership of the EEC in the <a href="/wiki/1975_United_Kingdom_European_Communities_membership_referendum" title="1975 United Kingdom European Communities membership referendum">1975 national referendum</a><sup id="cite_ref-upi19750604_256-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-upi19750604-256">&#91;249&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Single_European_Act" title="Single European Act">Single European Act</a> of 1986, and obtained the <a href="/wiki/UK_rebate" title="UK rebate">UK rebate</a> on contributions,<sup id="cite_ref-kuper20190620_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kuper20190620-257">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup> but she believed that the role of the organisation should be limited to ensuring free trade and effective competition, and feared that the EEC approach was at odds with her views on smaller government and deregulation.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESenden20049_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESenden20049-258">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup> Believing that the single market would result in political integration,<sup id="cite_ref-kuper20190620_257-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kuper20190620-257">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher\'s opposition to further <a href="/wiki/European_integration" title="European integration">European integration</a> became more pronounced during her premiership and particularly after her third government in 1987.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup> In her Bruges speech in 1988, Thatcher outlined her opposition to proposals from the EEC,<sup id="cite_ref-Bruges_255-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bruges-255">&#91;248&#93;</a></sup> forerunner of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, for a federal structure and increased centralisation of decision-making:<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942"/></p><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>We have not successfully rolled back the frontiers of the state in Britain, only to see them re-imposed at a European level, with a European super-state exercising a new dominance from Brussels.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESenden20049_258-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESenden20049-258">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup></p></blockquote>\n<p>Thatcher, sharing the concerns of French president <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Mitterrand" title="Fran\xc3\xa7ois Mitterrand">Fran\xc3\xa7ois Mitterrand</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">&#91;253&#93;</a></sup> was initially opposed to <a href="/wiki/German_reunification" title="German reunification">German reunification</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">&#91;nb 8&#93;</a></sup> telling Gorbachev that it "would lead to a change to postwar borders, and we cannot allow that because such a development would undermine the stability of the whole international situation and could endanger our security". She expressed concern that a united Germany would align itself more closely with the Soviet Union and move away from NATO.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEG\xc3\xb6rtemaker2006198_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEG\xc3\xb6rtemaker2006198-263">&#91;255&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In March 1990, Thatcher held a Chequers seminar on the subject of German reunification that was attended by members of her cabinet and historians such as <a href="/wiki/Norman_Stone" title="Norman Stone">Norman Stone</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Urban" title="George Urban">George Urban</a>, <a href="/wiki/Timothy_Garton_Ash" title="Timothy Garton Ash">Timothy Garton Ash</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gordon_A._Craig" title="Gordon A. Craig">Gordon A. Craig</a>. During the seminar, Thatcher described "what Urban called \'saloon bar <a href="/wiki/Clich%C3%A9" title="Clich\xc3\xa9">clich\xc3\xa9s</a>\' about the German character, including \'<a href="/wiki/Angst" title="Angst">angst</a>, aggressiveness, <a href="/wiki/Assertiveness" title="Assertiveness">assertiveness</a>, bullying, <a href="/wiki/Egotism" title="Egotism">egotism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Inferiority_complex" title="Inferiority complex">inferiority complex</a> &#91;and&#93; <a href="/wiki/Sentimentality" title="Sentimentality">sentimentality</a><span style="padding-right:.15em;">\'</span>". Those present were shocked to hear Thatcher\'s utterances and "appalled" at how she was "apparently unaware" about the post-war <a href="/wiki/German_collective_guilt" title="German collective guilt">German collective guilt</a> and Germans\' attempts to <a href="/wiki/Vergangenheitsbew%C3%A4ltigung" title="Vergangenheitsbew\xc3\xa4ltigung">work through their past</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell2011a634_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell2011a634-264">&#91;256&#93;</a></sup> The words of the meeting were leaked by her foreign-policy advisor <a href="/wiki/Charles_Powell,_Baron_Powell_of_Bayswater" title="Charles Powell, Baron Powell of Bayswater">Charles Powell</a> and, subsequently, her comments were met with fierce backlash and controversy.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>During the same month, West German chancellor <a href="/wiki/Helmut_Kohl" title="Helmut
