Kohl">Helmut Kohl</a> reassured Thatcher that he would keep her "informed of all his intentions about unification",<sup id="cite_ref-Bowcott_266-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bowcott-266">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup> and that he was prepared to disclose "matters which even his cabinet would not know".<sup id="cite_ref-Bowcott_266-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bowcott-266">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Challenges_to_leadership_and_resignation">Challenges to leadership and resignation</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/1989_Conservative_Party_leadership_election" title="1989 Conservative Party leadership election">1989 Conservative Party leadership election</a> and <a href="/wiki/1990_Conservative_Party_leadership_election" title="1990 Conservative Party leadership election">1990 Conservative Party leadership election</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Thatcher_reviews_troops.jpg" class="image"><img alt="photograph of a 64-year-old Thatcher" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Thatcher_reviews_troops.jpg/170px-Thatcher_reviews_troops.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="190" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Thatcher_reviews_troops.jpg/255px-Thatcher_reviews_troops.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Thatcher_reviews_troops.jpg/340px-Thatcher_reviews_troops.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1738" data-file-height="1942" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Thatcher_reviews_troops.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Thatcher reviewing the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Bermuda_Regiment" title="Royal Bermuda Regiment">Royal Bermuda Regiment</a> in early 1990</div></div></div>\n<p>During her premiership Thatcher had the second-lowest average approval rating (40%) of any post-war prime minister. Since Nigel Lawson\'s resignation as Chancellor in October 1989,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrewe1991_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrewe1991-267">&#91;259&#93;</a></sup> polls consistently showed that she was less popular than her party.<sup id="cite_ref-ridley_268-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ridley-268">&#91;260&#93;</a></sup> A self-described conviction politician, Thatcher always insisted that she did not care about her poll ratings and pointed instead to her unbeaten election record.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">&#91;261&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In December 1989, Thatcher was challenged for the leadership of the Conservative Party by the little-known backbench MP <a href="/wiki/Sir_Anthony_Meyer,_3rd_Baronet" title="Sir Anthony Meyer, 3rd Baronet">Sir Anthony Meyer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-89election_270-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89election-270">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup> Of the 374 Conservative MPs eligible to vote, 314 voted for Thatcher and 33 for Meyer. Her supporters in the party viewed the result as a success, and rejected suggestions that there was discontent within the party.<sup id="cite_ref-89election_270-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89election-270">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Opinion polls in September 1990 reported that Labour had established a 14% lead over the Conservatives,<sup id="cite_ref-howe_271-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-howe-271">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup> and by November the Conservatives had been trailing Labour for 18&#160;months.<sup id="cite_ref-ridley_268-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ridley-268">&#91;260&#93;</a></sup> These ratings, together with Thatcher\'s combative personality and tendency to override collegiate opinion, contributed to further discontent within her party.<sup id="cite_ref-resign-nyt_272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-resign-nyt-272">&#91;264&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In July 1989, Thatcher removed Geoffrey Howe as <a href="/wiki/Foreign_Secretary" title="Foreign Secretary">foreign secretary</a> after he and Lawson had forced her to agree to a plan for Britain to join the <a href="/wiki/European_Exchange_Rate_Mechanism" title="European Exchange Rate Mechanism">European Exchange Rate Mechanism</a> (ERM). Britain joined the ERM in October 1990. On 1 November 1990, Howe, by then the last remaining member of Thatcher\'s original 1979 cabinet, resigned from his position as <a href="/wiki/Deputy_Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Deputy Prime Minister of the United Kingdom">deputy prime minister</a>, ostensibly over her open hostility to moves towards <a href="/wiki/European_Monetary_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="European Monetary Union">European Monetary Union</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-howe_271-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-howe-271">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">&#91;265&#93;</a></sup> In his resignation speech on 13 November, which was instrumental in Thatcher\'s downfall,<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">&#91;266&#93;</a></sup> Howe attacked Thatcher\'s openly dismissive attitude to the government\'s proposal for a new European currency competing against existing currencies (a "hard <a href="/wiki/European_Currency_Unit" title="European Currency Unit">ECU</a>"):\n</p>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>How on earth are the Chancellor and the Governor of the Bank of England, commending the hard ECU as they strive to, to be taken as serious participants in the debate against that kind of background noise? I believe that both the Chancellor and the Governor are cricketing enthusiasts, so I hope that there is no monopoly of cricketing metaphors. It is rather like sending your opening batsmen to the crease only for them to find, the moment the first balls are bowled, that their bats have been broken before the game by the team captain.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">&#91;267&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">&#91;268&#93;</a></sup></p></blockquote>\n<p>On 14 November, Michael Heseltine mounted a challenge for the leadership of the Conservative Party.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">&#91;269&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMarr2007473_278-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarr2007473-278">&#91;270&#93;</a></sup> Opinion polls had indicated that he would give the Conservatives a national lead over Labour.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">&#91;271&#93;</a></sup> Although Thatcher led on the first ballot with the votes of 204 Conservative MPs (54.8%) to 152 votes (40.9%) for Heseltine, with 16 abstentions, she was four votes short of the required 15% majority. A second ballot was therefore necessary.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams199866_280-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams199866-280">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher initially declared her intention to "fight on and fight to win" the second ballot, but consultation with her cabinet persuaded her to withdraw.<sup id="cite_ref-resign-nyt_272-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-resign-nyt-272">&#91;264&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-resign-bbc_281-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-resign-bbc-281">&#91;273&#93;</a></sup> After holding an audience with the Queen, calling other world leaders, and making one final Commons speech,<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">&#91;274&#93;</a></sup> on 28 November she left Downing Street in tears. She reportedly regarded her ousting as a betrayal.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMarr2007474_283-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarr2007474-283">&#91;275&#93;</a></sup> Her resignation was a shock to many outside Britain, with such foreign observers as <a href="/wiki/Henry_Kissinger" title="Henry Kissinger">Henry Kissinger</a> and Gorbachev expressing private consternation.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">&#91;276&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher was replaced as head of government and party leader by Chancellor John Major, whose lead over Heseltine in the second ballot was sufficient for Heseltine to drop out. Major oversaw an upturn in Conservative support in the 17&#160;months leading to the <a href="/wiki/1992_United_Kingdom_general_election" title="1992 United Kingdom general election">1992 general election</a>, and led the party to a fourth successive victory on 9 April 1992.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">&#91;277&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher had lobbied for Major in the leadership contest against Heseltine, but her support for him waned in later years.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">&#91;278&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Later_life">Later life</span></h2>\n<h3><span id="Return_to_backbenches:_1990.E2.80.931992"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Return_to_backbenches:_1990\xe2\x80\x931992">Return to backbenches: 1990\xe2\x80\x931992</span></h3>\n<p>Thatcher returned to the <a href="/wiki/Backbenches" class="mw-redirect" title="Backbenches">backbenches</a> as a constituency parliamentarian after leaving the premiership.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReitan2003118_287-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReitan2003118-287">&#91;279&#93;</a></sup> Her domestic approval rating recovered after her resignation, though public opinion remained divided  on whether her government had been good for the country.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrewe1991_267-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrewe1991-267">&#91;259&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ipsos_288-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ipsos-288">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup> Aged 66, she retired from the House of Commons at the 1992 general election, saying that leaving the Commons would allow her more freedom to speak her mind.<sup id="cite_ref-lords_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lords-289">&#91;281&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span id="Post-Commons:_1992.E2.80.932003"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-Commons:_1992\xe2\x80\x932003">Post-Commons: 1992\xe2\x80\x932003</span></h3>\n<p>On leaving the Commons, Thatcher became the first former British prime minister to set up a foundation;<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">&#91;282&#93;</a></sup> the British wing of the Margaret Thatcher Foundation was dissolved in 2005 due to financial difficulties.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">&#91;283&#93;</a></sup> She wrote two volumes of memoirs, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Downing_Street_Years" title="The Downing Street Years">The Downing Street Years</a></i> (1993) and <a href="/wiki/The_Path_to_Power_(Thatcher_book)" title="The Path to Power (Thatcher book)"><i>The Path to Power</i></a> (1995). In 1991, she and her husband Denis moved to a house in <a href="/wiki/Chester_Square" title="Chester Square">Chester Square</a>, a residential garden square in central London\'s <a href="/wiki/Belgravia" title="Belgravia">Belgravia</a> district.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">&#91;284&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher was hired by the tobacco company <a href="/wiki/Altria" title="Altria">Philip Morris</a> as a "geopolitical consultant" in July 1992, for $250,000 per year and an annual contribution of $250,000 to her foundation.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">&#91;285&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher earned $50,000 for each speech she delivered.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">&#91;286&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher became an advocate of <a href="/wiki/Independence_of_Croatia" title="Independence of Croatia">Croatian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Independence_of_Slovenia" class="mw-redirect" title="Independence of Slovenia">Slovenian</a> independence.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">&#91;287&#93;</a></sup> Commenting on the <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_Wars" title="Yugoslav Wars">Yugoslav Wars</a>, in a 1991 interview for <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Radiotelevision" class="mw-redirect" title="Croatian Radiotelevision">Croatian Radiotelevision</a>, she was critical of Western governments for not recognising the breakaway republics of Croatia and Slovenia as independent and for not supplying them with arms after the Serbian-led <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_Army" class="mw-redirect" title="Yugoslav Army">Yugoslav Army</a> attacked.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">&#91;288&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In August 1992 she called for NATO to stop the Serbian assault on <a href="/wiki/Gora%C5%BEde" title="Gora\xc5\xbede">Gora\xc5\xbede</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sarajevo" title="Sarajevo">Sarajevo</a>, to end <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_cleansing" title="Ethnic cleansing">ethnic cleansing</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Bosnian_War" title="Bosnian War">Bosnian War</a>, comparing the <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_cleansing_in_the_Bosnian_War" title="Ethnic cleansing in the Bosnian War">situation in Bosnia\xe2\x80\x93Herzegovina</a> to "the <a href="/wiki/Comparison_of_Nazism_and_Stalinism" title="Comparison of Nazism and Stalinism">barbarities of Hitler\'s and Stalin\'s</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">&#91;289&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>She made a series of speeches in the Lords criticising the <a href="/wiki/Maastricht_Treaty" title="Maastricht Treaty">Maastricht Treaty</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-lords_289-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lords-289">&#91;281&#93;</a></sup> describing it as "a treaty too far" and stated: "I could never have signed this treaty."<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">&#91;290&#93;</a></sup> She cited <a href="/wiki/A._V._Dicey" title="A. V. Dicey">A. V. Dicey</a> when arguing that, as all three main parties were in favour of the treaty, the people should have their say in a referendum.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">&#91;291&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher served as honorary <a href="/wiki/Chancellor_(education)" title="Chancellor (education)">chancellor</a> of the <a href="/wiki/College_of_William_%26_Mary" title="College of William &amp; Mary">College of William &amp; Mary</a> in Virginia from 1993 to 2000,<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">&#91;292&#93;</a></sup> while also serving as chancellor of the private <a href="/wiki/University_of_Buckingham" title="University of Buckingham">University of Buckingham</a> from 1992 to 1998,<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">&#91;293&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Kealey_302-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kealey-302">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup> a university she had formally opened in 1976 as the then education secretary.<sup id="cite_ref-Kealey_302-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kealey-302">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>After <a href="/wiki/Tony_Blair" title="Tony Blair">Tony Blair</a>\'s <a href="/wiki/1994_Labour_Party_leadership_election" title="1994 Labour Party leadership election">election as Labour Party leader</a> in 1994, Thatcher praised Blair as "probably the most formidable <a href="/wiki/Leader_of_the_Labour_Party_(UK)" title="Leader of the Labour Party (UK)">Labour leader</a> since <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Gaitskell" title="Hugh Gaitskell">Hugh Gaitskell</a>", adding: "I see a lot of socialism behind their front bench, but not in Mr Blair. I think he genuinely has moved."<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">&#91;295&#93;</a></sup> Blair responded in kind: "She was a thoroughly determined person, and that is an admirable quality."<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">&#91;296&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 1998, Thatcher called for the release of former Chilean dictator <a href="/wiki/Augusto_Pinochet" title="Augusto Pinochet">Augusto Pinochet</a> when <a href="/wiki/Indictment_and_arrest_of_Augusto_Pinochet" title="Indictment and arrest of Augusto Pinochet">Spain had him arrested</a> and sought to try him for human rights violations. She cited the help he gave Britain during the Falklands War.<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">&#91;297&#93;</a></sup> In 1999, she visited him while he was under house arrest near London.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">&#91;298&#93;</a></sup> Pinochet was released in March 2000 on medical grounds by Home Secretary <a href="/wiki/Jack_Straw" title="Jack Straw">Jack Straw</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">&#91;299&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Margaret_Thatcher.jpg" class="image"><img alt="photograph of a 75-year-old Thatcher" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Margaret_Thatcher.jpg/170px-Margaret_Thatcher.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="182" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Margaret_Thatcher.jpg/255px-Margaret_Thatcher.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Margaret_Thatcher.jpg/340px-Margaret_Thatcher.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1360" data-file-height="1452" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Margaret_Thatcher.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Thatcher touring the <a href="/wiki/Kennedy_Space_Center" title="Kennedy Space Center">Kennedy Space Center</a> in early 2001</div></div></div>\n<p>At the <a href="/wiki/2001_United_Kingdom_general_election" title="2001 United Kingdom general election">2001 general election</a>, Thatcher supported the Conservative campaign, as she had done in 1992 and 1997, and in the <a href="/wiki/2001_Conservative_Party_leadership_election" title="2001 Conservative Party leadership election">Conservative leadership election</a> following its defeat, she endorsed <a href="/wiki/Iain_Duncan_Smith" title="Iain Duncan Smith">Iain Duncan Smith</a> over <a href="/wiki/Kenneth_Clarke" title="Kenneth Clarke">Kenneth Clarke</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">&#91;300&#93;</a></sup> In 2002 she encouraged <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a> to aggressively tackle the "unfinished business" of <a href="/wiki/Iraq_under_Saddam_Hussein" class="mw-redirect" title="Iraq under Saddam Hussein">Iraq under Saddam Hussein</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Thatcher_NYT_309-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thatcher_NYT-309">&#91;301&#93;</a></sup> and praised Blair for his "strong, bold leadership" in standing with Bush in the <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">Iraq War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thatcher_Blair_Iraq_310-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thatcher_Blair_Iraq-310">&#91;302&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>She broached the same subject in her <i><a href="/wiki/Statecraft:_Strategies_for_a_Changing_World" title="Statecraft: Strategies for a Changing World">Statecraft: Strategies for a Changing World</a></i>, which was published in April 2002 and dedicated to Ronald Reagan, writing that there would be no peace in the Middle East until <a href="/wiki/Saddam" class="mw-redirect" title="Saddam">Saddam</a> was toppled. Her book also said that Israel must trade <a href="/wiki/Land_for_peace" title="Land for peace">land for peace</a>, and that the European Union (EU) was a "fundamentally unreformable", "classic utopian project, a monument to the vanity of intellectuals, a programme whose inevitable destiny is failure".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGloverEconomides201020_311-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGloverEconomides201020-311">&#91;303&#93;</a></sup> She argued that Britain should renegotiate its terms of membership or else <a href="/wiki/Brexit" title="Brexit">leave the EU</a> and join the <a href="/wiki/North_American_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="North American Free Trade Agreement">North American Free Trade Area</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">&#91;304&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Following several small strokes she was advised by her doctors not to engage in further public speaking.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">&#91;305&#93;</a></sup> In March 2002 she announced that on doctors\' advice she would cancel all planned speaking engagements and accept no more.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell2003796\xe2\x80\x93798_314-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell2003796\xe2\x80\x93798-314">&#91;306&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="quotebox pullquote floatright" style="width:25em; ; background-color: whitesmoke;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1012376600"/>\n<div class="quotebox-title" style="background-color: whitesmoke;">Extract from <i><a href="/wiki/The_Downing_Street_Years" title="The Downing Street Years">The Downing Street Years</a></i></div>\n<div class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style=""><q>Being Prime Minister is a lonely job. In a sense, it ought to be: you cannot lead from the crowd. But with Denis there I was never alone. What a man. What a husband. What a friend.</q></div>\n<p><cite class="right-aligned" style=""><a href="#CITEREFThatcher1993">Thatcher (1993</a>, p.&#160;23)</cite>\n</p>\n</div>\n<p>On 26 June 2003, Thatcher\'s husband Sir Denis died aged 88,<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">&#91;307&#93;</a></sup> and was cremated on 3 July at <a href="/wiki/Mortlake_Crematorium" title="Mortlake Crematorium">Mortlake Crematorium</a> in London.<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">&#91;308&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span id="Final_years:_2003.E2.80.932013"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Final_years:_2003\xe2\x80\x932013">Final years: 2003\xe2\x80\x932013</span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Margaret_Thatcher_DF-SD-06-15534.jpg" class="image"><img alt="photograph" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Margaret_Thatcher_DF-SD-06-15534.jpg/200px-Margaret_Thatcher_DF-SD-06-15534.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="130" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Margaret_Thatcher_DF-SD-06-15534.jpg/300px-Margaret_Thatcher_DF-SD-06-15534.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Margaret_Thatcher_DF-SD-06-15534.jpg/400px-Margaret_Thatcher_DF-SD-06-15534.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3008" data-file-height="1960" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Margaret_Thatcher_DF-SD-06-15534.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Thatcher arriving for the funeral of President Reagan in 2004</div></div></div>\n<p>On 11 June 2004, Thatcher (against doctor\'s orders) attended the <a href="/wiki/Death_and_state_funeral_of_Ronald_Reagan" title="Death and state funeral of Ronald Reagan">state funeral service for Ronald Reagan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">&#91;309&#93;</a></sup> She delivered her eulogy via videotape; in view of her health, the message had been pre-recorded several months earlier.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">&#91;310&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">&#91;311&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher flew to California with the Reagan entourage, and attended the memorial service and interment ceremony for the president at the <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan_Presidential_Library" title="Ronald Reagan Presidential Library">Ronald Reagan Presidential Library</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">&#91;312&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2005, Thatcher criticised the way the decision to <a href="/wiki/2003_invasion_of_Iraq" title="2003 invasion of Iraq">invade Iraq</a> had been made two years previously. Although she still supported the intervention to topple Saddam Hussein, she said that (as a scientist) she would always look for "facts, evidence and proof", before committing the armed forces.<sup id="cite_ref-grice_235-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grice-235">&#91;228&#93;</a></sup> She celebrated her 80th birthday on 13 October at the <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_Oriental_Hyde_Park,_London" title="Mandarin Oriental Hyde Park, London">Mandarin Oriental Hotel</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hyde_Park,_London" title="Hyde Park, London">Hyde Park, London</a>; guests included the Queen, the <a href="/wiki/Prince_Philip,_Duke_of_Edinburgh" title="Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh">Duke of Edinburgh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Princess_Alexandra,_The_Honourable_Lady_Ogilvy" title="Princess Alexandra, The Honourable Lady Ogilvy">Princess Alexandra</a> and Tony Blair.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">&#91;313&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_Howe,_Baron_Howe_of_Aberavon" class="mw-redirect" title="Geoffrey Howe, Baron Howe of Aberavon">Geoffrey Howe, Baron Howe of Aberavon</a>, was also in attendance and said of his former leader: "Her real triumph was to have transformed not just one party but two, so that when Labour did eventually return, the great bulk of Thatcherism was accepted as irreversible."<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">&#91;314&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">Thatcher in the US, 2006</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Thatcher_2006_September_11_event.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Thatcher photographed standing with Dick and Lynne Cheney" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Thatcher_2006_September_11_event.jpg/200px-Thatcher_2006_September_11_event.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Thatcher_2006_September_11_event.jpg/300px-Thatcher_2006_September_11_event.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Thatcher_2006_September_11_event.jpg/400px-Thatcher_2006_September_11_event.jpg 2x" data-file-width="515" data-file-height="343" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Thatcher (<i>left</i><span style="padding-left:0.15em;">&#41;</span> at a Washington memorial service on the fifth anniversary of the 9/11 attacks</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Margaret_Thatcher_060912-F-0193C-006.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Thatcher photographed sharing a laugh with Rumsfeld and Pace" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Margaret_Thatcher_060912-F-0193C-006.jpg/200px-Margaret_Thatcher_060912-F-0193C-006.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="135" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Margaret_Thatcher_060912-F-0193C-006.jpg/300px-Margaret_Thatcher_060912-F-0193C-006.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Margaret_Thatcher_060912-F-0193C-006.jpg/400px-Margaret_Thatcher_060912-F-0193C-006.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4065" data-file-height="2737" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Thatcher with <a href="/wiki/Donald_Rumsfeld" title="Donald Rumsfeld">Donald Rumsfeld</a> and <a href="/wiki/General_Pace" class="mw-redirect" title="General Pace">General Pace</a> at the Pentagon</div></div></div></div></div>\n<p>In 2006, Thatcher attended the <a href="/wiki/Patriot_Day" title="Patriot Day">official Washington, D.C. memorial service</a> to commemorate the fifth anniversary of the <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">11 September attacks</a> on the US. She was a guest of Vice-President <a href="/wiki/Dick_Cheney" title="Dick Cheney">Dick Cheney</a>, and met Secretary of State <a href="/wiki/Condoleezza_Rice" title="Condoleezza Rice">Condoleezza Rice</a> during her visit.<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">&#91;315&#93;</a></sup> In February 2007 Thatcher became the first <a href="/wiki/Living_prime_ministers_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Living prime ministers of the United Kingdom">living British prime minister</a> to be honoured with a <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Margaret_Thatcher_(Palace_of_Westminster)" title="Statue of Margaret Thatcher (Palace of Westminster)">statue in the Houses of Parliament</a>. The bronze statue stands opposite <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Winston_Churchill,_Palace_of_Westminster" title="Statue of Winston Churchill, Palace of Westminster">that of her political hero, Winston Churchill</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-bronze_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bronze-324">&#91;316&#93;</a></sup> and was unveiled on 21 February 2007 with Thatcher in attendance; she remarked in the <a href="/wiki/Members%27_Lobby" title="Members&#39; Lobby">Members\' Lobby</a> of the Commons: "I might have preferred iron \xe2\x80\x93 but bronze will do [...] It won\'t rust."<sup id="cite_ref-bronze_324-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bronze-324">&#91;316&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher was a public supporter of the <a href="/wiki/Prague_Declaration_on_European_Conscience_and_Communism" class="mw-redirect" title="Prague Declaration on European Conscience and Communism">Prague Declaration on European Conscience and Communism</a> and the resulting Prague Process, and sent a public letter of support to its preceding conference.<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">&#91;317&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>After collapsing at a <a href="/wiki/House_of_Lords" title="House of Lords">House of Lords</a> dinner, Thatcher, suffering <a href="/wiki/Low_blood_pressure" class="mw-redirect" title="Low blood pressure">low blood pressure</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">&#91;318&#93;</a></sup> was admitted to <a href="/wiki/St_Thomas%27_Hospital" title="St Thomas&#39; Hospital">St Thomas\' Hospital</a> in central London on 7 March 2008 for tests. In 2009 she was hospitalised again when she fell and broke her arm.<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">&#91;319&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher returned to 10 Downing Street in late November 2009 for the unveiling of an official portrait by artist <a href="/wiki/Richard_Stone_(painter)" title="Richard Stone (painter)">Richard Stone</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-ThatcherReturns_328-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ThatcherReturns-328">&#91;320&#93;</a></sup> an unusual honour for a living former prime minister. Stone was previously commissioned to paint portraits of the Queen and <a href="/wiki/Queen_Mother" class="mw-redirect" title="Queen Mother">Queen Mother</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ThatcherReturns_328-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ThatcherReturns-328">&#91;320&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>On 4 July 2011, Thatcher was to attend a ceremony for the unveiling of a 10&#160;ft (3.0&#160;m) statue to Ronald Reagan, outside the <a href="/wiki/Embassy_of_the_United_States,_London" title="Embassy of the United States, London">US Embassy</a> in London, but was unable to attend due to her frail health.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">&#91;321&#93;</a></sup> She last attended a sitting of the House of Lords on 19 July 2010,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUK_Parliament2012_330-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUK_Parliament2012-330">&#91;322&#93;</a></sup> and on 30 July 2011 it was announced that her office in the Lords had been closed.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">&#91;323&#93;</a></sup> Earlier that month, Thatcher was named the most competent prime minister of the past 30 years in an <a href="/wiki/Ipsos_MORI" title="Ipsos MORI">Ipsos MORI</a> poll.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">&#91;324&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher\'s daughter Carol <a href="https://en.wikinews.org/wiki/Margaret_Thatcher_suffering_from_dementia,_says_daughter" class="extiw" title="n:Margaret Thatcher suffering from dementia, says daughter">first revealed</a> that her mother had <a href="/wiki/Dementia" title="Dementia">dementia</a> in 2005,<sup id="cite_ref-Langley_333-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Langley-333">&#91;325&#93;</a></sup> saying "Mum doesn\'t read much any more because of her memory loss". In her 2008 memoir, Carol wrote that her mother "could hardly remember the beginning of a sentence by the time she got to the end".<sup id="cite_ref-Langley_333-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Langley-333">&#91;325&#93;</a></sup> She later recounted how she was first struck by her mother\'s dementia when, in conversation, Thatcher confused the Falklands and Yugoslav conflicts; she recalled the pain of needing to tell her mother repeatedly that her husband Denis was dead.<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">&#91;326&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Death_and_funeral:_2013">Death and funeral: 2013</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Death_and_funeral_of_Margaret_Thatcher" title="Death and funeral of Margaret Thatcher">Death and funeral of Margaret Thatcher</a></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Margaret_Thatcher_coffin_at_St._Pauls_X8A2604.jpg" class="image"><img alt="photograph" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Margaret_Thatcher_coffin_at_St._Pauls_X8A2604.jpg/200px-Margaret_Thatcher_coffin_at_St._Pauls_X8A2604.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="128" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Margaret_Thatcher_coffin_at_St._Pauls_X8A2604.jpg/300px-Margaret_Thatcher_coffin_at_St._Pauls_X8A2604.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Margaret_Thatcher_coffin_at_St._Pauls_X8A2604.jpg/400px-Margaret_Thatcher_coffin_at_St._Pauls_X8A2604.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3060" data-file-height="1959" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Thatcher\'s coffin being carried up the steps of <a href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral" title="St Paul&#39;s Cathedral">St Paul\'s Cathedral</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:MTgrave1.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="photograph" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/MTgrave1.jpeg/200px-MTgrave1.jpeg" decoding="async" width="200" height="149" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/MTgrave1.jpeg/300px-MTgrave1.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/MTgrave1.jpeg/400px-MTgrave1.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1936" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Plaques on the graves of Margaret and Denis Thatcher at the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Hospital_Chelsea" title="Royal Hospital Chelsea">Royal Hospital Chelsea</a></div></div></div></div></div>\n<p>Baroness Thatcher died on 8 April 2013, at the age of 87, after suffering a stroke. She had been staying at a suite in <a href="/wiki/The_Ritz_Hotel,_London" title="The Ritz Hotel, London">the Ritz Hotel</a> in London since December 2012 after having difficulty with stairs at her Chester Square home in Belgravia.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">&#91;327&#93;</a></sup> Her death certificate listed the primary causes of death as a "cerebrovascular accident" and "repeated <a href="/wiki/Transient_ischaemic_attack" class="mw-redirect" title="Transient ischaemic attack">transient ischaemic attack</a>";<sup id="cite_ref-Mason_336-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mason-336">&#91;328&#93;</a></sup> secondary causes were listed as a "<a href="/wiki/Carcinoma" title="Carcinoma">carcinoma</a> of the bladder" and dementia.<sup id="cite_ref-Mason_336-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mason-336">&#91;328&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="https://en.wikiquote.org/wiki/Death_and_funeral_of_Margaret_Thatcher" class="extiw" title="q:Death and funeral of Margaret Thatcher">Reactions to the news of Thatcher\'s death</a> were mixed across the UK, ranging from tributes lauding her as Britain\'s greatest-ever peacetime prime minister to public celebrations of her death and expressions of hatred and personalised vitriol.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">&#91;329&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Details of Thatcher\'s funeral had been agreed with her in advance.<sup id="cite_ref-Independent,_12_April_2013_338-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Independent,_12_April_2013-338">&#91;330&#93;</a></sup> She received a <a href="/wiki/State_funerals_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="State funerals in the United Kingdom">ceremonial funeral</a>, including full military honours, with a church service at <a href="/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral" title="St Paul&#39;s Cathedral">St Paul\'s Cathedral</a> on 17 April.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_339-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-339">&#91;331&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BBC_News,_9_April_2013_340-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_News,_9_April_2013-340">&#91;332&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Queen Elizabeth&#160;II and the Duke of Edinburgh attended her funeral,<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">&#91;333&#93;</a></sup> marking only the second time in the Queen\'s reign that she attended the funeral of any of <a href="/wiki/List_of_prime_ministers_of_Elizabeth_II" title="List of prime ministers of Elizabeth II">her former prime ministers</a>, after <a href="/wiki/Death_and_state_funeral_of_Winston_Churchill" title="Death and state funeral of Winston Churchill">that of Winston Churchill</a>, who received a <a href="/wiki/State_funeral" title="State funeral">state funeral</a> in 1965.<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">&#91;334&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>After the service at St Paul\'s, Thatcher\'s body was cremated at Mortlake Crematorium, where her husband had been cremated. On 28 September, a service for Thatcher was held in the All Saints Chapel of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Hospital_Chelsea" title="Royal Hospital Chelsea">Royal Hospital Chelsea</a>\'s Margaret Thatcher Infirmary. In a private ceremony, Thatcher\'s ashes were interred in the grounds of the hospital, next to those of her husband.<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">&#91;335&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BBC-intere_344-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-intere-344">&#91;336&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy">Legacy</span></h2>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_impact">Political impact</span></h3>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1013635363"/><table class="sidebar sidebar-collapse nomobile"><tbody><tr><td class="sidebar-pretitle">Part of <a href="/wiki/Category:Politics" title="Category:Politics">the politics series</a> on</td></tr><tr><th class="sidebar-title-with-pretitle" style="font-size: 175%"><a href="/wiki/Thatcherism" title="Thatcherism">Thatcherism</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-image"><a href="/wiki/File:Margaret_Thatcher_cropped2.png" class="image" title="Margaret Thatcher"><img alt="Margaret Thatcher" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Margaret_Thatcher_cropped2.png/180px-Margaret_Thatcher_cropped2.png" decoding="async" width="180" height="208" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Margaret_Thatcher_cropped2.png/270px-Margaret_Thatcher_cropped2.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Margaret_Thatcher_cropped2.png/360px-Margaret_Thatcher_cropped2.png 2x" data-file-width="1224" data-file-height="1412" /></a></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">\n<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed hlist"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="text-align: center">Philosophy</div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">\n<ul><li><b><a href="/wiki/Conservatism" title="Conservatism">Conservatism</a></b></li>\n<li><b><a href="/wiki/Neoliberalism" title="Neoliberalism">Neoliberalism</a></b></li></ul>\n<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Anti-communism" title="Anti-communism">Anti-communism</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Atlanticism" title="Atlanticism">Atlanticism</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Capitalism" title="Capitalism">Capitalism</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Entrepreneurship" title="Entrepreneurship">Entrepreneurship</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Euroscepticism" title="Euroscepticism">Euroscepticism</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Gladstonian_liberalism" title="Gladstonian liberalism">Gladstonian liberalism</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Globalization" title="Globalization">Globalisation</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Individualism" title="Individualism">Individualism</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Meritocracy" title="Meritocracy">Meritocracy</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Monetarism" title="Monetarism">Monetarism</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Supply-side_economics" title="Supply-side economics">Supply-side economics</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Privatization" title="Privatization">Privatisation</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Property-owning_democracy" title="Property-owning democracy">Property-owning democracy</a></li></ul></div></div></td>\n</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">\n<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed hlist"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="text-align: center">People</div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">\n<ul><li><b><a class="mw-selflink selflink">Margaret Thatcher</a></b></li></ul>\n<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Friedrich_Hayek" title="Friedrich Hayek">Friedrich Hayek</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Milton_Friedman" title="Milton Friedman">Milton Friedman</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Arthur_Seldon" title="Arthur Seldon">Arthur Seldon</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Keith_Joseph" title="Keith Joseph">Keith Joseph</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Ralph_Harris,_Baron_Harris_of_High_Cross" title="Ralph Harris, Baron Harris of High Cross">Ralph Harris</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Alan_Walters" title="Alan Walters">Alan Walters</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_Howe" title="Geoffrey Howe">Geoffrey Howe</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Nicholas_Ridley,_Baron_Ridley_of_Liddesdale" title="Nicholas Ridley, Baron Ridley of Liddesdale">Nicholas Ridley</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Norman_Tebbit" title="Norman Tebbit">Norman Tebbit</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Nigel_Lawson" title="Nigel Lawson">Nigel Lawson</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/John_Redwood" title="John Redwood">John Redwood</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Michael_Portillo" title="Michael Portillo">Michael Portillo</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Francis_Maude" title="Francis Maude">Francis Maude</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Sajid_Javid" title="Sajid Javid">Sajid Javid</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Priti_Patel" title="Priti Patel">Priti Patel</a></li></ul></div></div></td>\n</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">\n<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed plainlist"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="text-align: center">Organisations</div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">\n<ul><li><b><a href="/wiki/Conservative_Party_(UK)" title="Conservative Party (UK)">Conservative Party</a></b>&#160;/&#32;<a href="/wiki/Wets_and_dries" title="Wets and dries">"Dries"</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Bow_Group" title="Bow Group">Bow Group</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Bruges_Group_(United_Kingdom)" title="Bruges Group (United Kingdom)">Bruges Group</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Centre_for_Policy_Studies" title="Centre for Policy Studies">Centre for Policy Studies</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Conservative_Way_Forward" title="Conservative Way Forward">Conservative Way Forward</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/The_Freedom_Association" title="The Freedom Association">The Freedom Association</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/The_Heritage_Foundation" title="The Heritage Foundation">The Heritage Foundation</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Institute_of_Economic_Affairs" title="Institute of Economic Affairs">Institute of Economic Affairs</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Mont_Pelerin_Society" title="Mont Pelerin Society">Mont Pelerin Society</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/No_Turning_Back_(political_group)" title="No Turning Back (political group)">No Turning Back</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Selsdon_Group" title="Selsdon Group">Selsdon Group</a></li></ul></div></div></td>\n</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">\n<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed plainlist"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="text-align: center">Related movements</div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">\n<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Economic_rationalism" title="Economic rationalism">Economic rationalism in Australia</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Libertarianism_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Libertarianism in the United Kingdom">Libertarianism in the United Kingdom</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/New_Right" title="New Right">New Right</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Reaganomics" title="Reaganomics">Reaganomics in the United States</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Rogernomics" title="Rogernomics">Rogernomics in New Zealand</a></li></ul></div></div></td>\n</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-below plainlist" style="font-size: 95%">\n<ul><li><a href="/wiki/File:Capitalismlogo.svg" class="image"><img alt="Capitalismlogo.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Capitalismlogo.svg/16px-Capitalismlogo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="16" height="15" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Capitalismlogo.svg/24px-Capitalismlogo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Capitalismlogo.svg/32px-Capitalismlogo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="959" data-file-height="912" /></a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Portal:Capitalism" title="Portal:Capitalism">Capitalism&#32;portal</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/File:DodgerBlue_flag_waving.svg" class="image"><img alt="DodgerBlue flag waving.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/DodgerBlue_flag_waving.svg/15px-DodgerBlue_flag_waving.svg.png" decoding="async" width="15" height="16" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/DodgerBlue_flag_waving.svg/22px-DodgerBlue_flag_waving.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/DodgerBlue_flag_waving.svg/30px-DodgerBlue_flag_waving.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="249" data-file-height="268" /></a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Portal:Conservatism" title="Portal:Conservatism">Conservatism&#32;portal</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/File:2006_AEGold_Proof_Obv.png" class="image"><img alt="2006 AEGold Proof Obv.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/2006_AEGold_Proof_Obv.png/16px-2006_AEGold_Proof_Obv.png" decoding="async" width="16" height="16" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/2006_AEGold_Proof_Obv.png/24px-2006_AEGold_Proof_Obv.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/2006_AEGold_Proof_Obv.png/32px-2006_AEGold_Proof_Obv.png 2x" data-file-width="1770" data-file-height="1762" /></a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Portal:Libertarianism" title="Portal:Libertarianism">Libertarianism&#32;portal</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/File:A_coloured_voting_box.svg" class="image"><img alt="A coloured voting box.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/01/A_coloured_voting_box.svg/16px-A_coloured_voting_box.svg.png" decoding="async" width="16" height="16" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/01/A_coloured_voting_box.svg/24px-A_coloured_voting_box.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/01/A_coloured_voting_box.svg/32px-A_coloured_voting_box.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="160" data-file-height="160" /></a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Portal:Politics" title="Portal:Politics">Politics&#32;portal</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg" class="image"><img alt="Flag of the United Kingdom.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/16px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png" decoding="async" width="16" height="8" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/24px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/32px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600" /></a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Portal:United_Kingdom" title="Portal:United Kingdom">United Kingdom&#32;portal</a></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r992953826"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Thatcherism" title="Template:Thatcherism"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Thatcherism" title="Template talk:Thatcherism"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Thatcherism&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p>Thatcherism represented a systematic and decisive overhaul of the <a href="/wiki/Post-war_consensus" title="Post-war consensus">post-war consensus</a>, whereby the major political parties largely agreed on the central themes of <a href="/wiki/Keynesianism" class="mw-redirect" title="Keynesianism">Keynesianism</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Welfare_state_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Welfare state in the United Kingdom">welfare state</a>, nationalised industry, and close regulation of the economy, and high taxes. Thatcher generally supported the welfare state, while proposing to rid it of abuses.<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">&#91;nb 9&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>She promised in 1982 that the highly popular <a href="/wiki/National_Health_Service" title="National Health Service">National Health Service</a> was "safe in our hands".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlein1985_346-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlein1985-346">&#91;337&#93;</a></sup> At first she ignored the question of privatising nationalised industries. Heavily influenced by right-wing think tanks, and especially by <a href="/wiki/Sir_Keith_Joseph" class="mw-redirect" title="Sir Keith Joseph">Sir Keith Joseph</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMarr2007358_347-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarr2007358-347">&#91;338&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher broadened her attack. Thatcherism came to refer to her policies as well as aspects of her ethical outlook and personal style, including <a href="/wiki/Moral_absolutism" title="Moral absolutism">moral absolutism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nationalism" title="Nationalism">nationalism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Individualism" title="Individualism">interest in the individual</a>, and an uncompromising approach to achieving political goals.<sup id="cite_ref-eb_348-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eb-348">&#91;339&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">&#91;340&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">&#91;nb 10&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher defined her own political philosophy, in a major and controversial break with the <a href="/wiki/One-nation_conservatism" title="One-nation conservatism">"one-nation" conservatism</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell2011a530\xe2\x80\x93532_351-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell2011a530\xe2\x80\x93532-351">&#91;341&#93;</a></sup> of her predecessor Edward Heath, in a 1987 interview published in <i><a href="/wiki/Woman%27s_Own" title="Woman&#39;s Own">Woman\'s Own</a></i> magazine:\n</p>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>I think we have gone through a period when too many children and people have been given to understand "I have a problem, it is the Government\'s job to cope with it!" or "I have a problem, I will go and get a grant to cope with it!" "I am homeless, the Government must house me!" and so they are casting their problems on society and who is society? There is no such thing! There are individual men and women and there are families and no government can do anything except through people and people look to themselves first. It is our duty to look after ourselves and then also to help look after our neighbour and life is a reciprocal business and people have got the entitlements too much in mind without the obligations.<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">&#91;342&#93;</a></sup></p></blockquote>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Overview">Overview</span></h4>\n<p>The number of adults owning shares rose from 7 per cent to 25 per cent during her tenure, and more than a million families bought their council houses, giving an increase from 55 per cent to 67 per cent in <a href="/wiki/Owner-occupier" class="mw-redirect" title="Owner-occupier">owner-occupiers</a> from 1979 to 1990. The houses were sold at a discount of 33\xe2\x80\x9355 per cent, leading to large profits for some new owners. Personal wealth rose by 80 per cent in real terms during the 1980s, mainly due to rising house prices and increased earnings. Shares in the privatised utilities were sold below their market value to ensure quick and wide sales, rather than maximise national income.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMarr2007430_353-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarr2007430-353">&#91;343&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">&#91;344&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>The "Thatcher years" were also marked by periods of high unemployment and social unrest,<sup id="cite_ref-legacy-bbc_355-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-legacy-bbc-355">&#91;345&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">&#91;346&#93;</a></sup> and many critics on the left of the political spectrum fault her economic policies for the unemployment level; many of the areas affected by mass unemployment as well as her <a href="/wiki/Monetarism" title="Monetarism">monetarist</a> economic policies remained blighted for decades, by such social problems as <a href="/wiki/Drug_abuse" class="mw-redirect" title="Drug abuse">drug abuse</a> and family breakdown.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERichards200463_357-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERichards200463-357">&#91;347&#93;</a></sup> Unemployment did not fall below its May 1979 level during her tenure,<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">&#91;348&#93;</a></sup> only marginally falling below its April 1979 level in 1990.<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">&#91;349&#93;</a></sup> The long-term effects of her policies on manufacturing remain contentious.<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">&#91;350&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell2011a79_361-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell2011a79-361">&#91;351&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Speaking in Scotland in 2009, Thatcher insisted she had no regrets and was right to introduce the poll tax and withdraw subsidies from "outdated industries, whose markets were in terminal decline", subsidies that created "the culture of dependency, which had done such damage to Britain".<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">&#91;352&#93;</a></sup> Political economist <a href="/wiki/Susan_Strange" title="Susan Strange">Susan Strange</a> termed the neoliberal financial growth model "casino capitalism", reflecting her view that speculation and financial trading were becoming more important to the economy than industry.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGamble200916_363-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGamble200916-363">&#91;353&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Critics on the left describe her as divisive<sup id="cite_ref-greatestpm_364-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-greatestpm-364">&#91;354&#93;</a></sup> and say she condoned greed and selfishness.<sup id="cite_ref-legacy-bbc_355-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-legacy-bbc-355">&#91;345&#93;</a></sup> Leading Welsh politician <a href="/wiki/Rhodri_Morgan" title="Rhodri Morgan">Rhodri Morgan</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">&#91;355&#93;</a></sup> among others,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWest2012176Blundell201388_366-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWest2012176Blundell201388-366">&#91;356&#93;</a></sup> characterised Thatcher as a "<a href="/wiki/Marmite" title="Marmite">Marmite</a>" figure. Journalist <a href="/wiki/Michael_White_(journalist)" title="Michael White (journalist)">Michael White</a>, writing in the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%932008" title="Financial crisis of 2007\xe2\x80\x932008">2007\xe2\x80\x9308 financial crisis</a>, challenged the view that her reforms were still a net benefit.<sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">&#91;357&#93;</a></sup> Others consider her approach to have been "a mixed bag"<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERothbard1995chpt._63_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERothbard1995chpt._63-368">&#91;358&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">&#91;359&#93;</a></sup> and "&#91;a&#93; <a href="/wiki/Curate%27s_egg" title="Curate&#39;s egg">Curate\'s egg</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJohnson1991chpt._8_370-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJohnson1991chpt._8-370">&#91;360&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher did "little to advance the political cause of women" either within her party or the government.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEvans200425_371-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEvans200425-371">&#91;361&#93;</a></sup> <a href="#CITEREFBurns2009">Burns (2009</a>, p.&#160;234) states that some <a href="/wiki/Feminism_in_the_United_Kingdom" class="mw-redirect" title="Feminism in the United Kingdom">British feminists</a> regarded her as "an enemy". <a href="#CITEREFPurvis2013">Purvis (2013)</a> says that, although Thatcher had struggled laboriously against the sexist prejudices of her day to rise to the top, she made no effort to ease the path for other women. Thatcher did not regard <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_rights" title="Women&#39;s rights">women\'s rights</a> as requiring particular attention as she did not, especially during her premiership, consider that women were being deprived of their rights. She had once suggested the shortlisting of women by default for all public appointments, yet had also proposed that those with young children ought to leave the workforce.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGelb198958\xe2\x80\x9359_372-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGelb198958\xe2\x80\x9359-372">&#91;362&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher\'s stance on <a href="/wiki/Modern_immigration_to_the_United_Kingdom" title="Modern immigration to the United Kingdom">immigration</a> in the late 1970s was perceived as part of a rising racist public discourse,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitte201454_373-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitte201454-373">&#91;363&#93;</a></sup> which <a href="#CITEREFBarker1981">Barker (1981)</a> terms "<a href="/wiki/New_racism" class="mw-redirect" title="New racism">new racism</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChin200992_374-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChin200992-374">&#91;364&#93;</a></sup> In opposition, Thatcher believed that the National Front (NF) was winning over large numbers of Conservative voters with warnings against floods of immigrants. Her strategy was to undermine the NF narrative by acknowledging that many of <a href="/wiki/Support_base_of_the_National_Front_(UK)" title="Support base of the National Front (UK)">their voters</a> had serious concerns in need of addressing. In 1978 she criticised Labour immigration policy with the goal of attracting voters away from the NF and to the Conservatives.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitte201453\xe2\x80\x9354_375-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitte201453\xe2\x80\x9354-375">&#91;365&#93;</a></sup> Her rhetoric was followed by an increase in Conservative support at the expense of the NF. Critics on the left accused her of <a href="/wiki/Pandering_(politics)" class="mw-redirect" title="Pandering (politics)">pandering</a> to racism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFriedman200613_376-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFriedman200613-376">&#91;366&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">&#91;nb 11&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Many Thatcherite policies had an influence on the Labour Party,<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">&#91;370&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESeldon200714_382-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESeldon200714-382">&#91;371&#93;</a></sup> which returned to power in 1997 under Tony Blair. Blair rebranded the party "<a href="/wiki/New_Labour" title="New Labour">New Labour</a>" in 1994 with the aim of increasing its appeal beyond its traditional supporters,<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">&#91;372&#93;</a></sup> and to attract those who had supported Thatcher, such as the "<a href="/wiki/Essex_man" title="Essex man">Essex man</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">&#91;373&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher is said to have regarded the "New Labour" rebranding as her greatest achievement.<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">&#91;374&#93;</a></sup> In contrast to Blair, the Conservative Party leader at the time <a href="/wiki/William_Hague" title="William Hague">William Hague</a> attempted to distance himself and the party from Thatcher\'s economic policies in an attempt to gain public approval.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell2011a790_386-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell2011a790-386">&#91;375&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Shortly after Thatcher\'s death in 2013, Scottish first minister <a href="/wiki/Alex_Salmond" title="Alex Salmond">Alex Salmond</a> argued that her policies had the "unintended consequence" of encouraging <a href="/wiki/Scottish_devolution" class="mw-redirect" title="Scottish devolution">Scottish devolution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">&#91;376&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lord_Foulkes_of_Cumnock" class="mw-redirect" title="Lord Foulkes of Cumnock">Lord Foulkes of Cumnock</a> agreed on <i><a href="/wiki/Scotland_Tonight" title="Scotland Tonight">Scotland Tonight</a></i> that she had provided "the impetus" for devolution.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">&#91;377&#93;</a></sup> Writing for <i><a href="/wiki/The_Scotsman" title="The Scotsman">The Scotsman</a></i> in 1997, Thatcher argued against devolution on the basis that it would eventually lead to <a href="/wiki/Scottish_independence" title="Scottish independence">Scottish independence</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">&#91;378&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Reputation">Reputation</span></h4>\n<div class="quotebox pullquote floatright" style="width:25em; ; background-color: whitesmoke;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1012376600"/>\n<div class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">Margaret Thatcher was not merely the first woman and the longest-serving Prime Minister of modern times, but the most admired, most hated, most idolised and most vilified public figure of the second half of the twentieth century. To some she was the saviour of her country who [...] created a vigorous enterprise economy which twenty years later was still outperforming the more regulated economies of the Continent. To others, she was a narrow ideologue whose hard-faced policies legitimised greed, deliberately increased inequality [...] and destroyed the nation\'s sense of solidarity and civic pride. There is no reconciling these views: yet both are true.<sup id="cite_ref-Campbell_390-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Campbell-390">&#91;nb 12&#93;</a></sup></div>\n<p><cite class="right-aligned" style="">Biographer <a href="/wiki/John_Campbell_(biographer)" title="John Campbell (biographer)">John&#32;Campbell</a>&#160;(<a href="#CITEREFCampbell2011b">2011b</a>,&#8194;p.&#160;499)</cite>\n</p>\n</div>\n<p>Thatcher\'s <a href="/wiki/List_of_prime_ministers_of_the_United_Kingdom_by_length_of_tenure" title="List of prime ministers of the United Kingdom by length of tenure">tenure of 11 years and 209 days</a> as British prime minister was the longest since <a href="/wiki/Lord_Salisbury" class="mw-redirect" title="Lord Salisbury">Lord Salisbury</a> (13 years and 252 days, in three spells) and the longest continuous period in office since <a href="/wiki/Lord_Liverpool" class="mw-redirect" title="Lord Liverpool">Lord Liverpool</a> (14 years and 305 days).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGardinerThompson201312_391-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGardinerThompson201312-391">&#91;379&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">&#91;380&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Having led the Conservative Party to victory in three consecutive general elections, twice in a landslide, she ranks among the most popular party leaders in British history in terms of votes cast for the winning party; over 40&#160;million ballots were cast in total for the Conservatives under her leadership.<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">&#91;381&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">&#91;382&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">&#91;383&#93;</a></sup> Her electoral successes were dubbed a "historic <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/hat_trick" class="extiw" title="wikt:hat trick">hat trick</a>" by the British press in 1987.<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">&#91;384&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher ranked highest among living persons in the 2002 BBC poll <i><a href="/wiki/100_Greatest_Britons" title="100 Greatest Britons">100 Greatest Britons</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">&#91;385&#93;</a></sup> In 1999, <a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)"><i>Time</i></a> deemed Thatcher one of the <a href="/wiki/Time_100:_The_Most_Important_People_of_the_Century" title="Time 100: The Most Important People of the Century">100 most important people of the 20th century</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">&#91;386&#93;</a></sup> In 2015 she topped a poll by <i><a href="/wiki/Scottish_Widows" title="Scottish Widows">Scottish Widows</a></i>, a major financial services company, as the most influential woman of the past 200 years;<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">&#91;387&#93;</a></sup> and in 2016 topped <a href="/wiki/BBC_Radio_4" title="BBC Radio 4">BBC Radio 4</a>\'s <i><a href="/wiki/Woman%27s_Hour" title="Woman&#39;s Hour">Woman\'s Hour</a> Power List</i> of women judged to have had the biggest impact on female lives over the past 70 years.<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">&#91;388&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401">&#91;389&#93;</a></sup> In 2020, <i>Time</i> magazine included Thatcher\'s name on its list of 100 Women of the Year. She was chosen as the Woman of the Year 1982, the year in which the Falklands War began under her command and resulted in the British victory.<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">&#91;390&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In contrast to her relatively poor average approval rating as prime minister,<sup id="cite_ref-Ipsos_288-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ipsos-288">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher has since <a href="/wiki/Historical_rankings_of_prime_ministers_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Historical rankings of prime ministers of the United Kingdom">ranked highly in retrospective opinion polling</a> and, according to <a href="/wiki/YouGov" title="YouGov">YouGov</a>, she is "see[n] in overall positive terms" by the British public.<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">&#91;391&#93;</a></sup> She was voted the fourth-greatest British prime minister of the 20th century in a poll of 139 academics organised by <a href="/wiki/MORI" class="mw-redirect" title="MORI">MORI</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">&#91;392&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cultural_depictions">Cultural depictions</span></h3>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cultural_depictions_of_Margaret_Thatcher" title="Cultural depictions of Margaret Thatcher">Cultural depictions of Margaret Thatcher</a></div>\n<p>According to theatre critic <a href="/wiki/Michael_Billington_(critic)" title="Michael Billington (critic)">Michael Billington</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">&#91;393&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher left an "emphatic mark" on the arts while prime minister.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">&#91;394&#93;</a></sup> One of the earliest satires of Thatcher as prime minister involved satirist <a href="/wiki/John_Wells_(satirist)" title="John Wells (satirist)">John Wells</a> (as writer and performer), actress <a href="/wiki/Janet_Brown" title="Janet Brown">Janet Brown</a> (voicing Thatcher) and future <i><a href="/wiki/Spitting_Image" title="Spitting Image">Spitting Image</a></i> producer <a href="/wiki/John_Lloyd_(producer)" title="John Lloyd (producer)">John Lloyd</a> (as co-producer), who in 1979 were teamed up by producer <a href="/wiki/Martin_Lewis_(humorist)" title="Martin Lewis (humorist)">Martin Lewis</a> for the satirical audio album <a href="/wiki/The_Iron_Lady_(album)" title="The Iron Lady (album)"><i>The Iron Lady</i></a>, which consisted of skits and songs satirising Thatcher\'s rise to power. The album was released in September 1979.<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">&#91;395&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">&#91;396&#93;</a></sup> Thatcher was heavily satirised on <i>Spitting Image</i>, and <i>The Independent</i> labelled her "every stand-up\'s dream".<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">&#91;397&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher was the subject or the inspiration for 1980s <a href="/wiki/Protest_song" title="Protest song">protest songs</a>. Musicians <a href="/wiki/Billy_Bragg" title="Billy Bragg">Billy Bragg</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paul_Weller" title="Paul Weller">Paul Weller</a> helped to form the <a href="/wiki/Red_Wedge" title="Red Wedge">Red Wedge</a> collective to support Labour in opposition to Thatcher.<sup id="cite_ref-songs_410-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-songs-410">&#91;398&#93;</a></sup> Known as "Maggie" by supporters and opponents alike, the chant song "<a href="/wiki/Maggie_Out" title="Maggie Out">Maggie Out</a>" became a signature rallying cry among the left during the latter half of her premiership.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVinen20091947\xe2\x80\x931948Barr2013178,_235_411-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVinen20091947\xe2\x80\x931948Barr2013178,_235-411">&#91;399&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher was parodied by Wells in several media. He collaborated with <a href="/wiki/Richard_Ingrams" title="Richard Ingrams">Richard Ingrams</a> on the spoof "<a href="/wiki/Dear_Bill" title="Dear Bill">Dear Bill</a>" letters, which ran as a column in <i><a href="/wiki/Private_Eye" title="Private Eye">Private Eye</a></i> magazine; they were also published in book form and became a West End stage revue titled <i>Anyone for Denis?</i>, with Wells in the role of Thatcher\'s husband. It was followed by a <a href="/wiki/Anyone_for_Denis%3F_(video)" title="Anyone for Denis? (video)">1982 TV special</a> directed by <a href="/wiki/Dick_Clement" title="Dick Clement">Dick Clement</a>, in which Thatcher was played by <a href="/wiki/Angela_Thorne" title="Angela Thorne">Angela Thorne</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">&#91;400&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Since her premiership, Thatcher has been portrayed in a number of television programmes, documentaries, films and plays.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">&#91;401&#93;</a></sup> She was portrayed by <a href="/wiki/Patricia_Hodge" title="Patricia Hodge">Patricia Hodge</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ian_Curteis" title="Ian Curteis">Ian Curteis</a>\'s long unproduced <i><a href="/wiki/The_Falklands_Play" title="The Falklands Play">The Falklands Play</a></i> (2002) and by <a href="/wiki/Andrea_Riseborough" title="Andrea Riseborough">Andrea Riseborough</a> in the TV film <i><a href="/wiki/The_Long_Walk_to_Finchley" title="The Long Walk to Finchley">The Long Walk to Finchley</a></i> (2008). She is the protagonist in two films, played by <a href="/wiki/Lindsay_Duncan" title="Lindsay Duncan">Lindsay Duncan</a> in <a href="/wiki/Margaret_(2009_film)" title="Margaret (2009 film)"><i>Margaret</i></a> (2009) and by <a href="/wiki/Meryl_Streep" title="Meryl Streep">Meryl Streep</a> in <a href="/wiki/The_Iron_Lady_(film)" title="The Iron Lady (film)"><i>The Iron Lady</i></a> (2011),<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">&#91;402&#93;</a></sup> in which she is depicted as suffering from dementia or <a href="/wiki/Alzheimer%27s_disease" title="Alzheimer&#39;s disease">Alzheimer\'s disease</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">&#91;403&#93;</a></sup> She is a main character in the <a href="/wiki/The_Crown_(season_4)" title="The Crown (season 4)">fourth season</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Crown_(TV_series)" title="The Crown (TV series)">The Crown</a></i>, played by <a href="/wiki/Gillian_Anderson" title="Gillian Anderson">Gillian Anderson</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">&#91;404&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span id="Titles.2C_awards_and_honours"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Titles,_awards_and_honours">Titles, awards and honours</span></h2>\n<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Honours_of_Margaret_Thatcher" title="Honours of Margaret Thatcher">Honours of Margaret Thatcher</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Margaret_Thatcher_awarded_Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom.jpg" class="image"><img alt="photograph" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Margaret_Thatcher_awarded_Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom.jpg/220px-Margaret_Thatcher_awarded_Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Margaret_Thatcher_awarded_Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom.jpg/330px-Margaret_Thatcher_awarded_Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Margaret_Thatcher_awarded_Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom.jpg/440px-Margaret_Thatcher_awarded_Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3150" data-file-height="2121" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Margaret_Thatcher_awarded_Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Thatcher receiving the <a href="/wiki/Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom" title="Presidential Medal of Freedom">Presidential Medal of Freedom</a> in 1991</div></div></div>\n<p>Thatcher became a <a href="/wiki/Privy_Council_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Privy Council of the United Kingdom">privy councillor</a> (PC) on becoming a secretary of state in 1970.<sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">&#91;405&#93;</a></sup> She was the first woman entitled to full membership rights as an honorary member of the <a href="/wiki/Carlton_Club" title="Carlton Club">Carlton Club</a> on becoming Leader of the Conservative Party in 1975.<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">&#91;406&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>As prime minister, Thatcher received two honorary distinctions:\n</p>\n<ul><li><span class="vevent">24&#160;October&#160;1979<span style="display:none">&#160;(<span class="bday dtstart published updated">1979-10-24</span>)</span>: <span class="summary">Honorary Fellowship (Hon.) of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Institute_of_Chemistry" title="Royal Institute of Chemistry">Royal Institute of Chemistry</a> (FRIC),<sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419">&#91;407&#93;</a></sup> which was merged into the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Society_of_Chemistry" title="Royal Society of Chemistry">Royal Society of Chemistry</a> (FRSC) the following year;<sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">&#91;408&#93;</a></sup></span></span></li>\n<li><span class="vevent">1&#160;July&#160;1983<span style="display:none">&#160;(<span class="bday dtstart published updated">1983-07-01</span>)</span>: <span class="summary"><a href="/wiki/Fellow_of_the_Royal_Society" title="Fellow of the Royal Society">Fellowship of the Royal Society</a> (FRS), a point of controversy among some of the then-existing Fellows.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE&#39;&#39;New_Scientist&#39;&#39;1983_421-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE&#39;&#39;New_Scientist&#39;&#39;1983-421">&#91;409&#93;</a></sup></span></span></li></ul>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:177px;max-width:177px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">Orders of chivalry</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:83px;max-width:83px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:24px;overflow:hidden"><a href="/wiki/File:Order_of_the_Garter_UK_ribbon.png" class="image"><img alt="Ribbon of the Order of the Garter"
