class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_Garter" title="Order of the Garter">The Garter</a> <br /> <span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom"><img alt="United Kingdom" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/20px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png" decoding="async" width="20" height="10" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/30px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png 1.5x,    <br /></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:90px;max-width:90px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:24px;overflow:hidden"><a href="/wiki/File:Ord.GoodHope-ribbon.gif" class="image"><img alt="Ribbon of the Order of Good Hope" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Ord.GoodHope-ribbon.gif/88px-Ord.GoodHope-ribbon.gif" decoding="async" width="88" height="24" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Ord.GoodHope-ribbon.gif/132px-Ord.GoodHope-ribbon.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Ord.GoodHope-ribbon.gif/176px-Ord.GoodHope-ribbon.gif 2x" data-file-width="218" data-file-height="60" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Order_of_Good_Hope" title="Order of Good Hope">Good Hope</a> <br /> <span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa"><img alt="South Africa" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Flag_of_South_Africa_%281982%E2%80%931994%29.svg/20px-Flag_of_South_Africa_%281982%E2%80%931994%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="20" height="13" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Flag_of_South_Africa_%281982%E2%80%931994%29.svg/30px-Flag_of_South_Africa_%281982%E2%80%931994%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Flag_of_South_Africa_%281982%E2%80%931994%29.svg/40px-Flag_of_South_Africa_%281982%E2%80%931994%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600" /></a></span> 1991                  <br /></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:84px;max-width:84px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:24px;overflow:hidden"><a href="/wiki/File:Order_of_Merit_(Commonwealth_realms)_ribbon.png" class="image"><img alt="Ribbon of the Order of Merit" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Order_of_Merit_%28Commonwealth_realms%29_ribbon.png/82px-Order_of_Merit_%28Commonwealth_realms%29_ribbon.png" decoding="async" width="82" height="25" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3a/Order_of_Merit_%28Commonwealth_realms%29_ribbon.png 1.5x" data-file-width="100" data-file-height="30" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Order_of_Merit" title="Order of Merit">Merit</a> <br /> <span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom"><img alt="United Kingdom" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/20px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png" decoding="async" width="20" height="10" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/30px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600" /></a></span> 1990                  <br /></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:89px;max-width:89px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:24px;overflow:hidden"><a href="/wiki/File:Order_of_St_John_(UK)_ribbon_-vector.svg" class="image"><img alt="Ribbon of the Order of St John" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Order_of_St_John_%28UK%29_ribbon_-vector.svg/87px-Order_of_St_John_%28UK%29_ribbon_-vector.svg.png" decoding="async" width="87" height="25" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Order_of_St_John_%28UK%29_ribbon_-vector.svg/131px-Order_of_St_John_%28UK%29_ribbon_-vector.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Order_of_St_John_%28UK%29_ribbon_-vector.svg/174px-Order_of_St_John_%28UK%29_ribbon_-vector.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="442" data-file-height="126" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Order_of_Saint_John_(chartered_1888)" title="Order of Saint John (chartered 1888)">St John</a> <br /> <span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom"><img alt="United Kingdom" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/20px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png" decoding="async" width="20" height="10" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/30px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600" /></a></span> 1991                  <br /></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">Shown are the ribbons for each Order bestowed on Thatcher.</div></div></div></div>\n<p>Two weeks after her resignation, Thatcher was appointed Member of the <a href="/wiki/Order_of_Merit" title="Order of Merit">Order of Merit</a> (OM) by the Queen. Her husband Denis was <a href="/wiki/Thatcher_baronets" title="Thatcher baronets">made a hereditary baronet</a> at the same time;<sup id="cite_ref-OMBarontecy_422-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OMBarontecy-422">&#91;410&#93;</a></sup> as his wife, Thatcher was entitled to use the <a href="/wiki/Style_(form_of_address)" title="Style (form of address)">honorific style</a> "Lady",<sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">&#91;411&#93;</a></sup> an automatically conferred title that she declined to use.<sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">&#91;412&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">&#91;413&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">&#91;414&#93;</a></sup> She would be made Lady Thatcher in her own right on her subsequent <a href="/wiki/Ennoblement" title="Ennoblement">ennoblement</a> in the House of Lords.<sup id="cite_ref-Tuohy_427-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tuohy-427">&#91;415&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>In the Falklands, <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Thatcher_Day" class="mw-redirect" title="Margaret Thatcher Day">Margaret Thatcher Day</a> has been marked each 10 January since 1992,<sup id="cite_ref-Reuters-January_428-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters-January-428">&#91;416&#93;</a></sup> commemorating her first visit to the Islands in January 1983, six months after the <a href="/wiki/Aftermath_of_the_Falklands_War" title="Aftermath of the Falklands War">end of the Falklands War</a> in June 1982.<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">&#91;417&#93;</a></sup>\n</p><p>Thatcher became a <a href="/wiki/Member_of_the_Lords" class="mw-redirect" title="Member of the Lords">member of the Lords</a> in 1992 with a <a href="/wiki/Life_peer" title="Life peer">life peerage</a> as Baroness Thatcher, of <a href="/wiki/Kesteven" title="Kesteven">Kesteven</a> in the <a href="/wiki/County_of_Lincolnshire" class="mw-redirect" title="County of Lincolnshire">County of Lincolnshire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-lords_289-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lords-289">&#91;281&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">&#91;418&#93;</a></sup> Subsequently, the <a href="/wiki/College_of_Arms" title="College of Arms">College of Arms</a> granted her usage of a <a href="/wiki/Armorial_of_prime_ministers_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Armorial of prime ministers of the United Kingdom">personal coat of arms</a>; she was allowed to revise these arms on her appointment as <a href="/wiki/Lady_of_the_Order_of_the_Garter" class="mw-redirect" title="Lady of the Order of the Garter">Lady of the Order of the Garter</a> (LG) in 1995, the highest order of <a href="/wiki/Chivalry" title="Chivalry">chivalry</a> for women.<sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431">&#91;419&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<table class="mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" style="font-size:95%; margin:auto; text-align:center">\n<caption class="nowrap" style="background:whitesmoke; border:1px solid lightgrey; font-weight:bold; padding-left:1em; padding-right:1em">Coats of arms of Baroness Thatcher\n</caption>\n<tbody><tr>\n<td>Pre\xe2\x80\x93<a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_Garter" title="Order of the Garter">Garter</a> appointment</td>\n<td style="width:0.2em;">\n</td>\n<td colspan="2">Post\xe2\x80\x93Garter appointment\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="border:1px solid lightgrey; padding:0.7em"><a href="/wiki/File:Coat_of_Arms_of_Margaret_Thatcher,_The_Baroness_Thatcher_(1992%E2%80%931995).svg" class="image" title="illustration"><img 2x" data-file-width="1470" data-file-height="1297" /></a></td>\n<td>\n</td>\n<td colspan="2" style="border:1px solid lightgrey; padding:0.7em"><a href="/wiki/File:Coat_of_Arms_of_Margaret_Thatcher,_The_Baroness_Thatcher_(1995%E2%80%932013).svg" class="image" title="illustration"><img alt="illustration" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Coat_of_Arms_of_Margaret_Thatcher%2C_The_Baroness_Thatcher_%281995%E2%80%932013%29.svg/150px-Coat_of_Arms_of_Margaret_Thatcher%2C_The_Baroness_Thatcher_%281995%E2%80%932013%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="150" height="132" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Coat_of_Arms_of_Margaret_Thatcher%2C_The_Baroness_Thatcher_%281995%E2%80%932013%29.svg/225px-Coat_of_Arms_of_Margaret_Thatcher%2C_The_Baroness_Thatcher_%281995%E2%80%932013%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Coat_of_Arms_of_Margaret_Thatcher%2C_The_Baroness_Thatcher_%281995%E2%80%932013%29.svg/300px-Coat_of_Arms_of_Margaret_Thatcher%2C_The_Baroness_Thatcher_%281995%E2%80%932013%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1480" data-file-height="1307" /></a><span style="padding-left:0.7em;">&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/File:Coat_of_Arms_of_Margaret_Thatcher,_The_Baroness_Thatcher_(1995%E2%80%932013)_(Variant).svg" class="image" title="illustration of variant"><img alt="illustration of variant" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Coat_of_Arms_of_Margaret_Thatcher%2C_The_Baroness_Thatcher_%281995%E2%80%932013%29_%28Variant%29.svg/150px-Coat_of_Arms_of_Margaret_Thatcher%2C_The_Baroness_Thatcher_%281995%E2%80%932013%29_%28Variant%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="150" height="132" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Coat_of_Arms_of_Margaret_Thatcher%2C_The_Baroness_Thatcher_%281995%E2%80%932013%29_%28Variant%29.svg/225px-Coat_of_Arms_of_Margaret_Thatcher%2C_The_Baroness_Thatcher_%281995%E2%80%932013%29_%28Variant%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Coat_of_Arms_of_Margaret_Thatcher%2C_The_Baroness_Thatcher_%281995%E2%80%932013%29_%28Variant%29.svg/300px-Coat_of_Arms_of_Margaret_Thatcher%2C_The_Baroness_Thatcher_%281995%E2%80%932013%29_%28Variant%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1470" data-file-height="1297" /></a>\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>1992\xe2\x80\x931995</td>\n<td>\n</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Lozenge_(heraldry)" title="Lozenge (heraldry)">Lozenge</a>: 1995\xe2\x80\x932013\n</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Escutcheon_(heraldry)" title="Escutcheon (heraldry)">Escutcheon</a>: 1995\xe2\x80\x932013\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p>In the US, Thatcher received the <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan_Freedom_Award" title="Ronald Reagan Freedom Award">Ronald Reagan Freedom Award</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432">&#91;420&#93;</a></sup> and was later designated Patron of <a href="/wiki/The_Heritage_Foundation" title="The Heritage Foundation">The Heritage Foundation</a> in 2006,<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">&#91;421&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">&#91;422&#93;</a></sup> where she established the Margaret Thatcher Center for Freedom.<sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435">&#91;423&#93;</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Publications">Publications</span></h2>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011217839">.mw-parser-output .refbegin{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents>ul{margin-left:0}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents>ul>li{margin-left:0;padding-left:3.2em;text-indent:-3.2em}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents ul,.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents ul li{list-style:none}@media(max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents>ul>li{padding-left:1.6em;text-indent:-1.6em}}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-100{font-size:100%}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-columns ul{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}</style><div class="refbegin" style="">\n<ul><li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"/><cite id="CITEREFThatcher_(1993)" class="citation book cs1"><a href="#CITEREFThatcher1993">Thatcher (1993)</a>. <a href="/wiki/The_Downing_Street_Years" title="The Downing Street Years"><i>The Downing Street Years</i></a>. HarperCollins. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-00-255049-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-00-255049-9"><bdi>978-0-00-255049-9</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Downing+Street+Years&amp;rft.pub=HarperCollins&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-00-255049-9&amp;rft.au=Thatcher+%281993%29&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMargaret+Thatcher" class="Z3988"></span></li>\n<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"/><cite id="CITEREFThatcher_(1995)" class="citation book cs1"><a href="#CITEREFThatcher1995">Thatcher (1995)</a>. <a href="/wiki/The_Path_to_Power_(Thatcher_book)" title="The Path to Power (Thatcher book)"><i>The Path to Power</i></a>. HarperCollins. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-00-255050-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-00-255050-5"><bdi>978-0-00-255050-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Path+to+Power&amp;rft.pub=HarperCollins&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-00-255050-5&amp;rft.au=Thatcher+%281995%29&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMargaret+Thatcher" class="Z3988"></span></li>\n<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"/><cite id="CITEREFThatcher_(2003)_harvp_error:_no_target:_CITEREFThatcher2003_(help)Category:Harv_and_Sfn_no-target_errors" class="citation book cs1"><a href="#CITEREFThatcher2003">Thatcher (2003)</a><span class="error harv-error" style="display: none; font-size:100%"> harvp error: no target: CITEREFThatcher2003 (<a href="/wiki/Category:Harv_and_Sfn_template_errors" title="Category:Harv and Sfn template errors">help</a>)</span>. <a href="/wiki/Statecraft:_Strategies_for_a_Changing_World" title="Statecraft: Strategies for a Changing World"><i>Statecraft: Strategies for a Changing World</i></a>. Harper Perennial. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-06-095912-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-06-095912-8"><bdi>978-0-06-095912-8</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Statecraft%3A+Strategies+for+a+Changing+World&amp;rft.pub=Harper+Perennial&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-06-095912-8&amp;rft.au=Thatcher+%282003%29%3Cspan+class%3D%22error+harv-error%22+style%3D%22display%3A+none%3B+font-size%3A100%25%22%3E+harvp+error%3A+no+target%3A+CITEREFThatcher2003+%28help%29%3C%2Fspan%3ECategory%3AHarv+and+Sfn+no-target+errors&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMargaret+Thatcher" title="Portal:England">England portal</a></span></li></ul></div>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h3>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-columns references-column-width" style="column-width: 30em;">\n<ol class="references">\n<li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In her foreword to the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Conservative_Party_(UK)_general_election_manifestos" title="List of Conservative Party (UK) general election manifestos">Conservative manifesto</a> of 1979, she wrote of "a feeling of helplessness, that we are a once great nation that has somehow fallen behind".<sup id="cite_ref-PoliticalStuff.co.uk_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PoliticalStuff.co.uk-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Winning support from a majority of her party in the first round of votes, Thatcher fell four votes short of the required 15% margin to win the contest outright.  Her fall has been characterised as "a rare <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Coup d&#39;\xc3\xa9tat">coup d\'\xc3\xa9tat</a> at the top of the British politics: the first since <a href="/wiki/Lloyd_George" class="mw-redirect" title="Lloyd George">Lloyd George</a> sawed <a href="/wiki/Asquith" class="mw-redirect" title="Asquith">Asquith</a> off at the knees in 1916."<sup id="cite_ref-Heffer_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Heffer-3">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-90"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-90">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFJames1977">James (1977</a>, pp.&#160;119\xe2\x80\x93120): <q>The hang-up has always been the voice. Not the timbre so much as, well, the <em>tone</em> \xe2\x80\x93 the condescending explanatory whine which treats the squirming interlocutor as an eight-year-old child with personality deficiencies. It has been fascinating, recently, to watch her striving to eliminate this. BBC2 <i>News Extra</i> on Tuesday night rolled a clip from May 1973 demonstrating the Thatcher sneer at full pitch. (She was saying that she wouldn\'t <em>dream</em> of seeking the leadership.) She sounded like a cat sliding down a blackboard.</q><sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-95"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-95">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Thatcher succeeded in completely suppressing her Lincolnshire dialect except when under stress, notably after provocation from <a href="/wiki/Denis_Healey" title="Denis Healey">Denis Healey</a> in the Commons in 1983, when she accused the <a href="/wiki/Shadow_Cabinet_of_Michael_Foot" title="Shadow Cabinet of Michael Foot">Labour frontbench</a> of being <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/frit#Etymology_2" class="extiw" title="wikt:frit"><i>frit</i></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-197"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-197">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In retirement, Thatcher became <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_scepticism" class="mw-redirect" title="Climate change scepticism">sceptical</a> about her policy, rejecting <a href="/wiki/Climate_alarmism" class="mw-redirect" title="Climate alarmism">climate alarmism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">&#91;192&#93;</a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-219"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-219">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFCannadine2017">Cannadine (2017)</a>: <q>In many ways they were very different figures: he was sunny, genial, charming, relaxed, upbeat, and with little intellectual curiosity or command of policy detail; she was domineering, belligerent, confrontational, tireless, hyperactive, and with an unrivalled command of facts and figures. But the chemistry between them worked. Reagan had been grateful for her interest in him at a time when the British establishment refused to take him seriously; she agreed with him about the importance of creating wealth, cutting taxes, and building up stronger defences against Soviet Russia; and both believed in liberty and free-market freedom, and in the need to outface what <a href="/wiki/Evil_Empire_speech" title="Evil Empire speech">Reagan would later call \'the evil empire\'</a>.</q></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-228"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-228">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><q>The United States has more than 330,000&#160;members of her forces in Europe to defend our liberty. Because they are here, they are subject to terrorist attack. It is inconceivable that they should be refused the right to use American aircraft and American pilots in the inherent right of self-defence, to defend their own people.</q><sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-262"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-262">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">She was decidedly cool towards reunification prior to 1990, but made no attempt to block it.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERatti2017chpt.&amp;nbsp;4_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERatti2017chpt.&amp;nbsp;4-261">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-345"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-345">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMoore2013">Moore (2013</a>, p.&#160;87): <q>Neither at the beginning of her career nor when she was prime minister, did Margaret Thatcher ever reject the wartime foundations of the welfare state, whether in health, social policy or education. In this she was less radical than her critics or some of her admirers supposed. Her concern was to focus more on abuse of the system, on bureaucracy and union militancy, and on the growth of what later came to be called the dependency culture, rather than on the system itself.</q></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-350"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-350">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFLawson1992">Lawson (1992</a>, p.&#160;64) lists the Thatcherite ideals as "a mixture of free markets, financial discipline, firm control over public expenditure, tax cuts, nationalism, \'Victorian values\' (of the <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Smiles" title="Samuel Smiles">Samuel Smiles</a> self-help variety), privatisation and a dash of populism".</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-380"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-380">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMitchellRussell1989">Mitchell &amp; Russell (1989)</a> posits that she had been misinterpreted and that <a href="/wiki/Race_(human_categorization)" title="Race (human categorization)">race</a> was never a focus of Thatcherism. By the 1980s, both the Conservatives and Labour had taken similar positions on immigration policy;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWard2004128Vinen2009227,_279_377-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWard2004128Vinen2009227,_279-377">&#91;367&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/British_Nationality_Act_1981" title="British Nationality Act 1981">British Nationality Act 1981</a> was passed with cross-party support.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHansen2000207\xe2\x80\x93208_378-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHansen2000207\xe2\x80\x93208-378">&#91;368&#93;</a></sup> There were no policies passed or proposed by ministers aimed at restricting legal immigration, nor would Thatcher highlight the subject of race in any of her later remarks.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnwar2001_379-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnwar2001-379">&#91;369&#93;</a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Campbell-390"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Campbell_390-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFCampbell2011a">Campbell (2011a</a>, p.&#160;800) also writes about a third view that can be argued: Thatcher "achieved much less" than she and her "<a href="/wiki/Dries" class="mw-redirect" title="Dries">dries</a>" would claim; she failed to curb public spending, diminish or privatise the <a href="/wiki/Welfare_state" title="Welfare state">welfare state</a>, change fundamental attitudes of the general public, or "enhance" freedom where she had instead <a href="/wiki/Centralisation" title="Centralisation">centralised</a> control over "many areas of national life".</span>\n</li>\n</ol></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Citations">Citations</span></h3>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1011085734"/><div class="reflist reflist-columns references-column-width" style="column-width: 20em;">\n<ol class="references">\n<li id="cite_note-PoliticalStuff.co.uk-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-PoliticalStuff.co.uk_1-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">\n <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.conservativemanifesto.com/1979/1979-conservative-manifesto.shtml">"1979 Conservative Party General Election Manifesto"</a>. <i>PoliticalStuff.co.uk</i><span class="reference-accessdate">.
